text:
# Introduction

In recent years, quantum walks have been studied extensively; see for some papers on this subject that have appeared in recent years. In the case of one-dimensional coined quantum walks, a substantial amount of progress has been made by using the beautiful observation of Cantero, Grünbaum, Moral, and Velázquez which relates the unitary time-one maps of such quantum walks with CMV matrices, a class of unitary operators which arise from a separate construction in the theory of orthogonal polynomials on the unit circle (OPUC) . In particular, this connection enables one to translate questions about the dynamics of a quantum walk into questions about the spectral theory of CMV matrices and OPUC, a subject for which an enormous number of powerful tools exist; see, e.g., .

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
In recent years, quantum walks have been studied extensively; see for some papers on this subject that have appeared in recent years. In the case of one-dimensional coined quantum walks, a substantial amount of progress has been made by using the beautiful observation of Cantero, Grünbaum, Moral, and Velázquez which relates the unitary time-one maps of such quantum walks with CMV matrices, a class of unitary operators which arise from a separate construction in the theory of orthogonal polynomials on the unit circle (OPUC) . In particular, this connection enables one to translate questions about the dynamics of a quantum walk into questions about the spectral theory of CMV matrices and OPUC, a subject for which an enormous number of powerful tools exist; see, e.g., .

In the present paper, we will study a particular one-dimensional coined quantum walk with quasi-periodically distributed coins. In general, a quasi-periodic walk is given by choosing a frequency vector $\beta \in {\mathbb T}^d \overset{\mathrm{def}}={\mathbb R}^d/{\mathbb Z}^d$ and a continuous map $\tau:{\mathbb T}^d \to {\mathbb U}(2)$, the group of $2 \times 2$ unitary matrices; given such a setup, one defines a family of quantum walks indexed by ${\mathbb T}^d$ by defining quantum coins on ${\mathbb Z}$ via $$C_n
=
C_{n,\theta}
=
\tau(n\beta+\theta),
\quad
n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}^d.$$ In this paper, we will focus on the scenario in which $d = 1$, and the map is the canonical imbedding of the circle into ${\mathbb U}(2)$ which identifies ${\mathbb T}$ with the rotation group ${\mathbb{SO}}(2)$. The unitary operators that arise from this construction appear in the physics literature, and they are closely related to the self-adjoint model known as the Almost-Mathieu Operator (AMO) , . In fact, the operators under consideration in this paper satisfy a very strong self-duality under the Fourier transform, and so they are most closely related to the *critical* AMO. We will show that these operators share many spectral characteristics with the critical AMO, such as purely singular continuous spectrum supported on a Cantor set of zero Lebesgue measure. In contrast to the walks discussed in this paper and , Cedzich *et al* have considered homogeneous quantum walks in quasi-periodic *electric fields* and quantum walks whose coins vary quasi-periodically in *time* .

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: We now precisely describe quantum walks on ${\mathbb Z}$. A *quantum walk* is described by a unitary operator on the Hilbert space $\mathcal{H} = \ell^2({\mathbb Z}) \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$, which models a state space in which a wave packet comes equipped with a “spin” at each integer site. Here, the elementary tensors of the form $\delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow$, and $\delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow$ with $n \in {\mathbb Z}$ comprise an orthonormal basis of ${\mathcal H}$ (where $\{e_\uparrow,e_\downarrow\}$ denotes the canonical basis of ${\mathbb C}^2$). A time-homogeneous quantum walk scenario is given as soon as coins $$\label{e.timehomocoins} C_{n} = \begin{pmatrix} c^{11}_{n} & c^{12}_{n} \\ c^{21}_{n} & c^{22}_{n} \end{pmatrix} \in {\mathbb U}(2), \quad n \in {\mathbb Z},$$ are specified. As one passes from time $t$ to time $t+1$, the update rule of the quantum walk applies the coins coordinatewise and shifts spin-up states to the right and spin-down states the the left, viz. $$\begin{aligned} \delta_{n} \otimes e_\uparrow & \mapsto c^{11}_{n} \delta_{n+1} \otimes e_\uparrow + c^{21}_{n} \delta_{n-1} \otimes e_\downarrow , \label{e.updaterule1} \\ \delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow & \mapsto c^{12}_{n} \delta_{n+1} \otimes e_\uparrow + c^{22}_{n} \delta_{n-1} \otimes e_\downarrow \label{e.updaterule2}. \end{aligned}$$ If we extend this by linearity and continuity to general elements of $\mathcal{H}$, this defines a unitary operator $U$ on $\mathcal{H}$. Equivalently, denote a typical element $\psi \in {\mathcal H}$ by $$\label{eq:typicalelt} \psi = \sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \left( \psi_{\uparrow,n} \delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow + \psi_{\downarrow,n} \delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow \right),$$ where one must have $$\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}\left( \left| \psi_{\uparrow,n} \right|^2 + \left| \psi_{\downarrow,n} \right|^2 \right) < \infty.$$ We may then describe the action of $U$ in coordinates via $$\label{eq:ucoord:def} \begin{split} [U\psi]_{\uparrow,n} & = c_{n-1}^{11} \psi_{\uparrow,n-1} + c_{n-1}^{12} \psi_{\downarrow,n-1}, \\ [U\psi]_{\downarrow,n} & = c_{n+1}^{21} \psi_{\uparrow,n+1} + c_{n+1}^{22} \psi_{\downarrow,n+1}. \end{split}$$ Next, order the basis of $\mathcal{H}$ by setting $\varphi_{2m} = \delta_m \otimes e_\uparrow$, $\varphi_{2m+1} = \delta_m \otimes e_\downarrow$ for $m \in {\mathbb Z}$ In this ordered basis, the matrix representation of $U : \mathcal{H} \to \mathcal{H}$ is given by $$\label{e.umatrixrep} U = \begin{pmatrix} \ddots &\ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&& \\ & 0 & 0 & c_1^{21} & c_1^{22} &&& \\ &c_{0}^{11} & c_{0}^{12} & 0 & 0 &&& \\ && & 0 & 0 & c_2^{21} & c_2^{22} & \\ && & c_1^{11} & c_1^{12} & 0 & 0 & \\ && && \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots \end{pmatrix},$$ where e.g. $U_{2,1}=c_0^{12}$, and $U_{1,3} = c_1^{22}$. This can be checked readily using the update rule [e.updaterule1]–[e.updaterule2]; compare . In this paper, we will consider the case of coined quantum walks on the integer lattice where the coins are distributed quasi-periodically according to the rule $$\label{eq:coindef} C_n = C_{n,\beta,\theta} = R_{2\pi(n\beta + \theta)}, \quad n \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $R_\gamma$ denotes counterclockwise rotation through the angle $\gamma$, i.e., $$R_\gamma = \begin{pmatrix} \cos\gamma & -\sin\gamma \\ \sin\gamma & \cos\gamma \end{pmatrix}, \quad \gamma \in {\mathbb R}.$$ We will denote the update rule associated to coins of the form [eq:coindef] by $U_{\beta,\theta}$. We will concentrate on the aperiodic case, in which $\beta \notin {\mathbb Q}$. In this case, translation by $\beta$ is a minimal transformation of ${\mathbb T}$, so there exists a uniform compact set $\Sigma_\beta \subseteq \partial {\mathbb D}$ such that $\sigma(U_{\beta,\theta}) = \Sigma_\beta$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Our main theorem characterizes the spectra and spectral type of $U_{\beta,\theta}$.

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text:
In this paper, we will consider the case of coined quantum walks on the integer lattice where the coins are distributed quasi-periodically according to the rule $$\label{eq:coindef} C_n = C_{n,\beta,\theta} = R_{2\pi(n\beta + \theta)}, \quad n \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $R_\gamma$ denotes counterclockwise rotation through the angle $\gamma$, i.e., $$R_\gamma = \begin{pmatrix} \cos\gamma & -\sin\gamma \\ \sin\gamma & \cos\gamma \end{pmatrix}, \quad \gamma \in {\mathbb R}.$$ We will denote the update rule associated to coins of the form [eq:coindef] by $U_{\beta,\theta}$. We will concentrate on the aperiodic case, in which $\beta \notin {\mathbb Q}$. In this case, translation by $\beta$ is a minimal transformation of ${\mathbb T}$, so there exists a uniform compact set $\Sigma_\beta \subseteq \partial {\mathbb D}$ such that $\sigma(U_{\beta,\theta}) = \Sigma_\beta$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Our main theorem characterizes the spectra and spectral type of $U_{\beta,\theta}$.
**Theorem 1**. ** *The unitary AMO exhibits purely singular Cantor spectrum at all irrational frequencies and all phases, and exhibits purely singular continuous spectrum at all irrational frequencies and almost all phases. More precisely, for every irrational $\beta \in {\mathbb T}$, the following statements hold true:* 1. * . For all $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$, the spectral type of $U_{\beta,\theta}$ is purely singular, i.e. $\sigma_{{\mathrm{ac}}}(U_{\beta,\theta}) = \emptyset$.* 2. * . For Lebesgue almost every $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$, the spectral type of $U_{\beta,\theta}$ is purely singular continuous.* 3. *. $\Sigma_\beta$ is a Cantor set of zero Lebesgue measure.*

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: Theorem [t:uamospec].1 is a consequence of Theorem  [t:uamospec].[t:singspec], Kotani Theory, and our Theorem 2 below which implies that Lyapunov exponent of the associated one-parameter family of dynamical systems (see [eq:tmdef] for the cocycle map) vanishes on the spectrum. In fact, we will prove something stronger than vanishing Lypapunov exponents on the spectrum in Theorem 2. In the language of the global theory of one-frequency analytic quasiperiodic cocycles, the cocycle dynamics on the spectrum are all of critical type. Let us describe this more carefully.

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: Theorem [t:uamospec].1 is a consequence of Theorem  [t:uamospec].[t:singspec], Kotani Theory, and our Theorem 2 below which implies that Lyapunov exponent of the associated one-parameter family of dynamical systems (see [eq:tmdef] for the cocycle map) vanishes on the spectrum. In fact, we will prove something stronger than vanishing Lypapunov exponents on the spectrum in Theorem 2. In the language of the global theory of one-frequency analytic quasiperiodic cocycles, the cocycle dynamics on the spectrum are all of critical type. Let us describe this more carefully. In , Avila has developed a powerful global theory for $1$-frequency quasiperiodic Schrödinger operators with real analytic potentials. Roughly speaking, for a real analytic function $v\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},{\mathbb R})$, one may define a family of operators $H_{\beta,v,\theta}:\ell^2({\mathbb Z})\rightarrow\ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ (known as *Schrödinger operators*) by $$\label{schrodingeroperators} [Hu]_n = u_{n-1} + u_{n+1} + v(\theta + n\beta)u_n, \quad u \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z}), \; n \in {\mathbb Z}.$$ Just like in the present paper, one may associate a one-parameter family of dynamical systems to the operators in [schrodingeroperators]. Specifically, one may define $A^{(E-v)}\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},\mathrm{SL(2,{\mathbb R})})$ by $$\label{schrodinger:cocycle} A(\theta)=A^{(E-v)}(\theta) = \begin{pmatrix}E-v(\theta) & -1\\ 1 & 0\end{pmatrix}, \quad E \in {\mathbb R}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Given a map as in [schrodinger:cocycle], one may define (positive) iterates via $$A_n(\theta) = A(\theta + (n-1)\beta) \cdots A(\theta + \beta) A(\theta),\ n>0.$$ Then classified each energy $E$ in the spectrum into three categories: 1. *supercritical*, if $\sup_{\theta\in{\mathbb T}}\|A_n(\theta)\|$ grows exponentially (positivity of Lyapunov exponent). 2. *subcritical*, if there is a uniform subexponential bound on the growth of $\|A_n(\zeta)\|$ through some band $|\mathrm{Im} \, \zeta|<\delta$. 3. *critical*, otherwise.

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: 3. *critical*, otherwise. According to Bourgain-Goldstein , supercritical energies correspond to pure point spectrum with exponentially localized states (Anderson Localization) for almost every frequency $\beta$. Avila recently demonstrated that subcritical energies correspond to absolutely continuous spectrum for all irrational frequencies $\beta$ (it was shown for exponentially Liouville frequency in ). However, critical energies remain mysterious, in general. Using his global theory , Avila showed that for any fixed irrational frequency $\beta$, for a (measure theoretically) typical potential $v\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},{\mathbb R})$, the operator $H_{\beta,v,\theta}$ has no critical energy. Thus the occurrence of critical energies is a very rare phenomenon. In fact, before our model in the present paper, the only operators known to display critical energies are the critical Almost Mathieu Operator (i.e. the operator given by [schrodingeroperators] with potential function $v(x) = 2\cos(2\pi x)$, which is also known as Harper’s Model) , and the extended Harper’s Model . Moreover, our model is the first unitary operator to display critical energies. The cocycle map associated to the operators $U_{\beta,\theta}$ (defined below in [eq:tmdef]) is meromorphic, not analytic. However it can be renormalized into an analytic map, which enables one to classify the energies in the spectrum as supercritical, subcritical and critical. Then, our stronger version of vanishing Lyapunov exponents on the spectrum is the following theorem:

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: **Theorem 2**. *For all irrational frequencies $\beta$, the operator family $(U_{\beta,\theta})_{\theta \in {\mathbb T}}$ is of critical type in sense that the associated renormalized matrix cocycle $(\beta,N^z)$ defined by [eq:tmNdef] is critical for every $z\in \Sigma_\beta$.*

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Introduction / Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice
text: The structure of the paper is as follows. In Section 2, we collect some useful background information and definitions. Section 3 discusses Aubry duality for the present model. In Section 4, we discuss the spectral type. We begin by proving Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:singspec]. Next, we exploit Aubry duality to prove that the spectral type is purely continuous for all frequencies and almost all phases, which completes the proof of Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:contspec]. In Section 5, we use global theory for singular one-frequency quasiperiodic cocycles to prove that the Lyapunov exponent vanishes on the spectrum. When combined with Kotani theory and the singular nature of the spectrum, this yields the conclusion of Theorem [t:uamospec].1, namely, that the spectrum is a Cantor set of zero Lebesgue measure. In Section 6, we work out an essential ingredient in our application of global theory, namely, a version of the theorem of Johnson for singular CMV matrices which identifies the resolvent set with the set of spectral parameters at which the associated matrix cocycles enjoy a dominated splitting. To the best of our knowledge, this is only known for nonsingular CMV matrices, i.e., CMV matrices whose Verblunsky coefficients are bounded away from the unit circle . We prove Johnson’s theorem in the singular case by adapting the techniques in Marx which were developed for singular Jacobi matrices. We expect that this result is of independent interest beyond quasiperiodic quantum walks, and so we formulate it in an appropriately general context.

heading.title: Quantum Walks on the Integer Lattice

section_path: Background / CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection
text:
## CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection

Given a sequence $\{ \alpha_n \}_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ of complex numbers where $\alpha_n \in \overline{{\mathbb D}} = \{ z \in {\mathbb C}: |z| \le 1\}$ for every $n \in {\mathbb Z}$, the associated *singular extended CMV matrix*, ${\mathcal E}= {\mathcal E}_\alpha$, is a unitary operator on $\ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ defined by the matrix representation $$\label{def:extcmv}
{\mathcal E}
=
\begin{pmatrix}
\ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&&  \\
& \overline{\alpha_0}\rho_{-1} & -\overline{\alpha_0}\alpha_{-1} & \overline{\alpha_1}\rho_0 & \rho_1\rho_0 &&&  \\
& \rho_0\rho_{-1} & -\rho_0\alpha_{-1} & -\overline{\alpha_1}\alpha_0 & -\rho_1 \alpha_0 &&&  \\
&&  & \overline{\alpha_2}\rho_1 & -\overline{\alpha_2}\alpha_1 & \overline{\alpha_3} \rho_2 & \rho_3\rho_2 & \\
&& & \rho_2\rho_1 & -\rho_2\alpha_1 & -\overline{\alpha_3}\alpha_2 & -\rho_3\alpha_2 &    \\
&& && \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &
\end{pmatrix},$$ where $\rho_n = \left( 1 - |\alpha_n|^2 \right)^{1/2}$ for every $n \in {\mathbb Z}$. We refer to $\{\alpha_n\}_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ as the sequence of *Verblunsky coefficients* of ${\mathcal E}$. Note that all unspecified matrix entries are implicitly assumed to be zero.

heading.title: CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection

section_path: Background / CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection
text: Given a sequence $\{ \alpha_n \}_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ of complex numbers where $\alpha_n \in \overline{{\mathbb D}} = \{ z \in {\mathbb C}: |z| \le 1\}$ for every $n \in {\mathbb Z}$, the associated *singular extended CMV matrix*, ${\mathcal E}= {\mathcal E}_\alpha$, is a unitary operator on $\ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ defined by the matrix representation $$\label{def:extcmv} {\mathcal E} = \begin{pmatrix} \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&& \\ & \overline{\alpha_0}\rho_{-1} & -\overline{\alpha_0}\alpha_{-1} & \overline{\alpha_1}\rho_0 & \rho_1\rho_0 &&& \\ & \rho_0\rho_{-1} & -\rho_0\alpha_{-1} & -\overline{\alpha_1}\alpha_0 & -\rho_1 \alpha_0 &&& \\ && & \overline{\alpha_2}\rho_1 & -\overline{\alpha_2}\alpha_1 & \overline{\alpha_3} \rho_2 & \rho_3\rho_2 & \\ && & \rho_2\rho_1 & -\rho_2\alpha_1 & -\overline{\alpha_3}\alpha_2 & -\rho_3\alpha_2 & \\ && && \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \end{pmatrix},$$ where $\rho_n = \left( 1 - |\alpha_n|^2 \right)^{1/2}$ for every $n \in {\mathbb Z}$. We refer to $\{\alpha_n\}_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ as the sequence of *Verblunsky coefficients* of ${\mathcal E}$. Note that all unspecified matrix entries are implicitly assumed to be zero. In , Cantero, Grünbaum, Moral, and Velázquez observed that one may connect CMV matrices and quantum walks; let us briefly describe this connection. If $\alpha_{2n} \equiv 0$, then the CMV matrix in [def:extcmv] becomes $$\label{e.ecmvoddzero} \mathcal{E} = \begin{pmatrix} \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&& \\ & 0 & 0 & \overline{\alpha_1} & \rho_1 &&& \\ & \rho_{-1} & - \alpha_{-1} & 0 & 0 &&& \\ &&& 0 & 0 & \overline{\alpha_3} & \rho_3 & \\ &&& \rho_1 & - \alpha_1 & 0 & 0 & \\ &&&& \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots \end{pmatrix};$$ the matrix in [e.ecmvoddzero] strongly resembles the matrix representation of $U$ in [e.umatrixrep]. Note, however, that $\rho_n \ge 0$ for all $n$, so [e.umatrixrep] and [e.ecmvoddzero] may not match exactly when $c_n^{kk}$ is not real and nonnegative. However, this can be easily resolved by conjugation with a suitable diagonal unitary; the interested reader is referred to for details.

heading.title: CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection

section_path: Background / CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection
text: In , Cantero, Grünbaum, Moral, and Velázquez observed that one may connect CMV matrices and quantum walks; let us briefly describe this connection. If $\alpha_{2n} \equiv 0$, then the CMV matrix in [def:extcmv] becomes $$\label{e.ecmvoddzero} \mathcal{E} = \begin{pmatrix} \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &&&& \\ & 0 & 0 & \overline{\alpha_1} & \rho_1 &&& \\ & \rho_{-1} & - \alpha_{-1} & 0 & 0 &&& \\ &&& 0 & 0 & \overline{\alpha_3} & \rho_3 & \\ &&& \rho_1 & - \alpha_1 & 0 & 0 & \\ &&&& \ddots & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots \end{pmatrix};$$ the matrix in [e.ecmvoddzero] strongly resembles the matrix representation of $U$ in [e.umatrixrep]. Note, however, that $\rho_n \ge 0$ for all $n$, so [e.umatrixrep] and [e.ecmvoddzero] may not match exactly when $c_n^{kk}$ is not real and nonnegative. However, this can be easily resolved by conjugation with a suitable diagonal unitary; the interested reader is referred to for details. In fact, in Section 6, we will define a class of generalized CMV matrices which includes both the standard formalism for CMV matrices and the operators that correspond to the quantum walks considered in the present paper. In particular, for our purposes later, let us also describe another factorization of $U$, which is closely tied to the usual $\mathcal L \mathcal M$ factorization of CMV matrices. More concretely, we have $U = JC'$, where $$\label{eq:Jdef} J: \delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow \mapsto \delta_{n-1} \otimes e_\downarrow, \quad J: \delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow \mapsto \delta_{n+1} \otimes e_\uparrow$$ and $$\label{eq:Cprimedef} C' :\delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow \mapsto c_n^{21} \delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow + c_n^{11} \delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow, \quad C' :\delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow \mapsto c_n^{22} \delta_n \otimes e_\uparrow + c_n^{12} \delta_n \otimes e_\downarrow.$$

heading.title: CMV Matrices and the CGMV Connection

section_path: Background / Transfer Matrices
text: ## Transfer Matrices

heading.title: Transfer Matrices

section_path: Background / Transfer Matrices
text: ## Transfer Matrices Since the present model is unitarily equivalent to a CMV matrix, we may write down $2 \times 2$ matrix cocycle which propagates solutions to the time-independent eigenvalue equation. More precisely, notice that $U=U_{\beta,\theta}$ is a finite-range operator; consequently, the definition [eq:ucoord:def] extends $U$ to a linear operator on the substantially larger vector space $${\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2 = \{ \psi: {\mathbb Z}\times\{\uparrow,\downarrow\} \to {\mathbb C}\}.$$ Thus, we may speak of generalized solutions of the eigenvalue equation $U \psi = z\psi$ where $\psi \in {\mathbb C}^{\mathbb Z}\otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ need not decay at $\pm \infty$. Specifically, suppose $\psi \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ satisfies $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z \psi$, where $z \in {\mathbb C}$, and define $\Psi: {\mathbb Z}\to {\mathbb C}^2$ by $$\Psi(n) = \begin{pmatrix} \psi_{\uparrow,n} \\ \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} \end{pmatrix}.$$ Using [eq:ucoord:def], we may write the equation $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z\psi$ in coordinates: $$\begin{aligned} z\psi_{\uparrow,n+1} & = \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} -\sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n} \\ z\psi_{\downarrow,n-1} & = \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} + \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n}, \end{aligned}$$ Solving these equations to get $\psi_{\uparrow,n+1}$ and $\psi_{\downarrow,n}$ in terms of $\psi_{\uparrow,n}$ and $\psi_{\downarrow,n-1}$, we have $$\Psi(n+1) = M^z(n\beta + \theta)\Psi(n) \text{ for all } n \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $M^z$ is defined by $$\label{eq:tmdef} M^z(x) = \sec(2\pi x) \begin{pmatrix} z^{-1} & -\sin(2\pi x) \\ -\sin(2\pi x) & z \end{pmatrix}, \quad x \in {\mathbb T}, \; z \in {\mathbb C}\setminus \{0\}.$$ Thus, the matrix cocycle induced by $M^z$ and rotation by $\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ will be of critical importance in our spectral analysis of $U$. As noted before, $M^z$ is meromorphic (as a function of $x$), so we will also make use of the renormalized analytic (singular) cocycle map $N^z$ defined by $$\label{eq:tmNdef} N^z(x) = -2i\cos(2\pi x) M^z(x) = \begin{pmatrix} -2iz^{-1} & 2i \sin(2\pi x) \\ 2i\sin(2\pi x) & -2iz \end{pmatrix}$$ for $x \in {\mathbb T}$ and $z \in {\mathbb C}\setminus \{0\}$.

heading.title: Transfer Matrices

section_path: Background / Transfer Matrices
text:
Since the present model is unitarily equivalent to a CMV matrix, we may write down $2 \times 2$ matrix cocycle which propagates solutions to the time-independent eigenvalue equation. More precisely, notice that $U=U_{\beta,\theta}$ is a finite-range operator; consequently, the definition [eq:ucoord:def] extends $U$ to a linear operator on the substantially larger vector space $${\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2 = \{ \psi: {\mathbb Z}\times\{\uparrow,\downarrow\} \to {\mathbb C}\}.$$ Thus, we may speak of generalized solutions of the eigenvalue equation $U \psi = z\psi$ where $\psi \in {\mathbb C}^{\mathbb Z}\otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ need not decay at $\pm \infty$. Specifically, suppose $\psi \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ satisfies $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z \psi$, where $z \in {\mathbb C}$, and define $\Psi: {\mathbb Z}\to {\mathbb C}^2$ by $$\Psi(n) = \begin{pmatrix} \psi_{\uparrow,n} \\ \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} \end{pmatrix}.$$ Using [eq:ucoord:def], we may write the equation $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z\psi$ in coordinates: $$\begin{aligned} z\psi_{\uparrow,n+1} & = \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} -\sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n} \\ z\psi_{\downarrow,n-1} & = \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} + \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n}, \end{aligned}$$ Solving these equations to get $\psi_{\uparrow,n+1}$ and $\psi_{\downarrow,n}$ in terms of $\psi_{\uparrow,n}$ and $\psi_{\downarrow,n-1}$, we have $$\Psi(n+1) = M^z(n\beta + \theta)\Psi(n) \text{ for all } n \in {\mathbb Z},$$ where $M^z$ is defined by $$\label{eq:tmdef} M^z(x) = \sec(2\pi x) \begin{pmatrix} z^{-1} & -\sin(2\pi x) \\ -\sin(2\pi x) & z \end{pmatrix}, \quad x \in {\mathbb T}, \; z \in {\mathbb C}\setminus \{0\}.$$ Thus, the matrix cocycle induced by $M^z$ and rotation by $\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ will be of critical importance in our spectral analysis of $U$. As noted before, $M^z$ is meromorphic (as a function of $x$), so we will also make use of the renormalized analytic (singular) cocycle map $N^z$ defined by $$\label{eq:tmNdef} N^z(x) = -2i\cos(2\pi x) M^z(x) = \begin{pmatrix} -2iz^{-1} & 2i \sin(2\pi x) \\ 2i\sin(2\pi x) & -2iz \end{pmatrix}$$ for $x \in {\mathbb T}$ and $z \in {\mathbb C}\setminus \{0\}$.
**Remark 4**. As a consequence of the CGMV connection, there are several other reasonable families of transfer matrices which encode various aspects of the spectral theory of $U_{\beta,\theta}$. In particular, we may notice that the operator family $U_{\beta,\theta}$ falls into the setting described in Section 6 with $T:x \mapsto x+\beta$ and $$f(x) = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad g(x) = \begin{pmatrix} \sin(2\pi x) & \cos(2\pi x) \\ \cos(2\pi x) & -\sin(2\pi x) \end{pmatrix}, \quad x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ In particular, using our $T$ and $g$ above, we have $$\begin{pmatrix} C'_{2k-2,2k-2} & C'_{2k-2,2k-1} \\ C'_{2k-1,2k-2} & C'_{2k-1,2k-1} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} c_{k-1}^{21} & c_{k-1}^{22} \\ c_{k-1}^{11} & c_{k-1}^{12} \end{pmatrix} = g(T^{k-1}\theta).$$ So $U_{\beta,\theta} = {\mathcal E}_{\theta-\beta}$ for $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Consequently, we may encode spectral characteristics of the family $(U_{\beta,\theta})_{\theta \in {\mathbb T}}$ using the (normalized) Gesztesy–Zinchenko transfer matrices for the family $({\mathcal E}_x)_{x \in {\mathbb T}}$ (defined in [eq:gzmatdef]), which are given by $$A^z(x) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= A_f^z(x) A_g^z(x) = \begin{pmatrix} z^{-1} & -\sin(2\pi x) \\ -\sin(2\pi x) & z \end{pmatrix}.$$ Thus, $N^z(x) = -2i A^z(x)$, so the cocycles $(\beta,N^z)$ and $(\beta,A^z)$ share all essential dynamical characteristics; in particular, $(\beta,N^z)$ admits a dominated splitting (defined later) if and only if $(\beta,A^z)$ admits a dominated splitting. Thus, Theorem 19 immediately yields the following for our model:

**Remark 4**. As a consequence of the CGMV connection, there are several other reasonable families of transfer matrices which encode various aspects of the spectral theory of $U_{\beta,\theta}$. In particular, we may notice that the operator family $U_{\beta,\theta}$ falls into the setting described in Section 6 with $T:x \mapsto x+\beta$ and $$f(x) = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad g(x) = \begin{pmatrix} \sin(2\pi x) & \cos(2\pi x) \\ \cos(2\pi x) & -\sin(2\pi x) \end{pmatrix}, \quad x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ In particular, using our $T$ and $g$ above, we have $$\begin{pmatrix} C'_{2k-2,2k-2} & C'_{2k-2,2k-1} \\ C'_{2k-1,2k-2} & C'_{2k-1,2k-1} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} c_{k-1}^{21} & c_{k-1}^{22} \\ c_{k-1}^{11} & c_{k-1}^{12} \end{pmatrix} = g(T^{k-1}\theta).$$ So $U_{\beta,\theta} = {\mathcal E}_{\theta-\beta}$ for $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Consequently, we may encode spectral characteristics of the family $(U_{\beta,\theta})_{\theta \in {\mathbb T}}$ using the (normalized) Gesztesy–Zinchenko transfer matrices for the family $({\mathcal E}_x)_{x \in {\mathbb T}}$ (defined in [eq:gzmatdef]), which are given by $$A^z(x) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= A_f^z(x) A_g^z(x) = \begin{pmatrix} z^{-1} & -\sin(2\pi x) \\ -\sin(2\pi x) & z \end{pmatrix}.$$ Thus, $N^z(x) = -2i A^z(x)$, so the cocycles $(\beta,N^z)$ and $(\beta,A^z)$ share all essential dynamical characteristics; in particular, $(\beta,N^z)$ admits a dominated splitting (defined later) if and only if $(\beta,A^z)$ admits a dominated splitting. Thus, Theorem 19 immediately yields the following for our model:
**Theorem 3**. *Fix $\beta \in {\mathbb T}\setminus {\mathbb Q}$, and denote by $\Sigma_\beta$ the common spectrum of $U_{\beta,\theta}$, $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Then $$\Sigma_\beta = \{ z \in \partial {\mathbb D}: (\beta,N^z) \notin {\mathcal{DS}}\}.$$*

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text:
# Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

In this section, we will discuss two versions of Aubry duality for the unitary Almost-Mathieu Operator. The first version expresses a classical version of duality between eigenfunctions and Bloch waves, while the second is a slightly more abstract framework which shows how (direct integrals of) the coin and shift operators are dual to one another via the Fourier transform. For the spectral analysis in the present paper, we only need the first version of duality. However, we explicitly work out the second version for two reasons. First, this second version is clearly a natural analogue of the usual Aubry duality transform, which has been extremely useful in the spectral analysis of the self-adjoint AMO as shown in . Secondly, this version reflects how some authors think about duality in the physics literature. Concretely, this version of duality puts the heuristic discussion in on a firm mathematical foundation.

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text:
In this section, we will discuss two versions of Aubry duality for the unitary Almost-Mathieu Operator. The first version expresses a classical version of duality between eigenfunctions and Bloch waves, while the second is a slightly more abstract framework which shows how (direct integrals of) the coin and shift operators are dual to one another via the Fourier transform. For the spectral analysis in the present paper, we only need the first version of duality. However, we explicitly work out the second version for two reasons. First, this second version is clearly a natural analogue of the usual Aubry duality transform, which has been extremely useful in the spectral analysis of the self-adjoint AMO as shown in . Secondly, this version reflects how some authors think about duality in the physics literature. Concretely, this version of duality puts the heuristic discussion in on a firm mathematical foundation. To describe the first version of duality, let us define the *inverse Fourier transform* of a sequence $u \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ by $$\widecheck{u}(x) = \sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} u_n e^{2\pi i n x}, \quad x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Additionally, for $f \in L^2({\mathbb T})$, we denote its *Fourier transform* by $$\label{eq:ftdef} \widehat f_k = \int_{\mathbb T}f(x) e^{-2\pi i k x} \, dx.$$ Given $\psi \in {\mathcal H}$, let us use [eq:typicalelt] to view it as a pair of $\ell^2$ sequences $\psi_\uparrow = (\psi_{\uparrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ and $\psi_\downarrow = (\psi_{\downarrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$. If we apply the inverse Fourier transform to the sequences $\psi_\uparrow$ and $\psi_\downarrow$ separately, we observe the following duality between solutions of $U \psi = z \psi$ and $U^\top \varphi = z \varphi$.
**Theorem 5**. *Suppose $\psi \in {\mathcal H}$ solves $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z \psi$. For a.e. $\xi \in {\mathbb T}$, we may define a state $\varphi = \varphi^\xi \in {\mathbb C}^{\mathbb Z}\otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ by $$\begin{aligned} \varphi_{\uparrow,n}^\xi & = e^{2\pi i n\theta} \left(\widecheck\psi_\uparrow(n\beta + \xi) + i \widecheck\psi_\downarrow(n\beta + \xi) \right) \\ \varphi_{\downarrow,n}^\xi & = e^{2\pi i n\theta}\left(i\widecheck\psi_\uparrow(n\beta + \xi) + \widecheck\psi_\downarrow(n\beta + \xi) \right). \end{aligned}$$ Then $U_{\beta,\xi}^\top \varphi^\xi = z \varphi^\xi$ for Lebesgue almost-every $\xi \in {\mathbb T}$.*

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text: To formulate the more abstract version of Aubry duality, we consider the direct integral of the family $U_{\beta,\theta}$ over $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. More specifically, consider the larger Hilbert space $\widetilde {\mathcal H}= L^2({\mathbb Z}\times {\mathbb T}\times \{\uparrow,\downarrow\})$, and denote by $U_\beta: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ the operator which acts on the fiber over $\theta$ by $U_{\beta,\theta}$, i.e.: $$\label{def:abstract:aubry} [U_\beta \psi](n,\theta,s) = (U_{\beta,\theta} \psi(\cdot,\theta,\cdot))(n,s), \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}.$$ In [def:abstract:aubry], $\psi(\cdot,\theta,\cdot)$ denotes the element $v \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z}) \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ with coordinates $v_{s,n} = \psi(n,\theta,s)$, with $n \in {\mathbb Z}$ and $s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$. It is not hard to check that $U_\beta$ defines a unitary operator from $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ to itself. Now, denote the Fourier transform on $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ by $\,\widehat{\cdot}$, that is, for $\varphi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}$, we define $$\widehat{\varphi}(n,\theta,s) = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} e^{-2\pi i m \theta} e^{-2\pi i n x} \varphi(m,x,s) \, dx, \quad n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}.$$ We then define the Aubry dual operator ${\mathcal A}: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ and a change of coordinates in spin space $\mathcal X: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ by $$[{\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,s) = \widehat{\psi}(n,n\beta+\theta,s), \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$$ and $$\begin{pmatrix} [\mathcal X \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [\mathcal X \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \begin{pmatrix} i & 1 \\ 1 & i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix}, \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}.$$

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text:
To formulate the more abstract version of Aubry duality, we consider the direct integral of the family $U_{\beta,\theta}$ over $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. More specifically, consider the larger Hilbert space $\widetilde {\mathcal H}= L^2({\mathbb Z}\times {\mathbb T}\times \{\uparrow,\downarrow\})$, and denote by $U_\beta: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ the operator which acts on the fiber over $\theta$ by $U_{\beta,\theta}$, i.e.: $$\label{def:abstract:aubry} [U_\beta \psi](n,\theta,s) = (U_{\beta,\theta} \psi(\cdot,\theta,\cdot))(n,s), \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}.$$ In [def:abstract:aubry], $\psi(\cdot,\theta,\cdot)$ denotes the element $v \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z}) \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ with coordinates $v_{s,n} = \psi(n,\theta,s)$, with $n \in {\mathbb Z}$ and $s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$. It is not hard to check that $U_\beta$ defines a unitary operator from $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ to itself. Now, denote the Fourier transform on $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ by $\,\widehat{\cdot}$, that is, for $\varphi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}$, we define $$\widehat{\varphi}(n,\theta,s) = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} e^{-2\pi i m \theta} e^{-2\pi i n x} \varphi(m,x,s) \, dx, \quad n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}.$$ We then define the Aubry dual operator ${\mathcal A}: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ and a change of coordinates in spin space $\mathcal X: \widetilde {\mathcal H}\to \widetilde {\mathcal H}$ by $$[{\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,s) = \widehat{\psi}(n,n\beta+\theta,s), \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}, \; s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$$ and $$\begin{pmatrix} [\mathcal X \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [\mathcal X \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \begin{pmatrix} i & 1 \\ 1 & i \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix}, \quad \psi \in \widetilde {\mathcal H}, \; n \in {\mathbb Z}, \; \theta \in {\mathbb T}.$$
**Theorem 6**. *For all irrational $\beta \in {\mathbb T}$, one has $$\mathcal X\mathcal A U_\beta = U_\beta^\top \mathcal A \mathcal X.$$*

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text: *Proof of Theorem 5.* Fix $\beta$ and $\theta$. First, let us recast $U\psi = z\psi$ in coordinates by using [eq:ucoord:def]: $$\begin{aligned} z\psi_{\uparrow,n} & = \psi_{\uparrow,n-1} c_{n-1}^{11} + \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} c_{n-1}^{12} \\ z\psi_{\downarrow,n} & = \psi_{\uparrow,n+1} c_{n+1}^{21} + \psi_{\downarrow,n+1} c_{n+1}^{22}. \end{aligned}$$ Multiply both sides (of the first equation) by $e^{2\pi i n x}$, sum over $n \in {\mathbb Z}$, and re-index the sum to get $$\begin{aligned} z \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) & = \sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}} \left( c_{n-1}^{11} \psi_{\uparrow,n-1} + c_{n-1}^{12} \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} \right) e^{2\pi i n x} \\ & = e^{2\pi i x} \sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}} \left(\cos(2\pi(n\beta+\theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} - \sin(2\pi(n\beta+\theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n} \right) e^{2\pi i n x} \end{aligned}$$ for Lebesgue almost-every $x \in {\mathbb T}$. Applying the exponential definitions of the trigonometric functions and the definition of the inverse Fourier transform, the calculation above yields $$\label{eq:psihatupw} z\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) = \frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2} \left( e^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) - ie^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \right)$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$, where $$w_\uparrow(x) = \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + i \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad w_\downarrow(x) = i\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Similarly, $$\label{eq:psihatdownw} z \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x) = \frac{e^{-2\pi i x}}{2}\left( -ie^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) + e^{-2\pi i \theta}w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \right)$$ for a.e. $x$. Using [eq:psihatupw] and [eq:psihatdownw] in conjunction with the definition of $w$, and the exponential definitions of the trigonometric functions, we get the following for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$: $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:dual:wup} z w_\uparrow(x) = & \cos(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) + \sin(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta), \\ \label{eq:dual:wdown} z w_\downarrow(x) = & - \sin(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) + \cos(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta). \end{aligned}$$ Now, let $\varphi =\varphi^\xi \in {\mathbb C}^{\mathbb Z}\otimes{\mathbb C}^2$ be defined as in the statement of Theorem 5, i.e., $\varphi^\xi_{s,n} = e^{2\pi i n \theta} w_s(n\beta + \xi)$ for $n \in {\mathbb Z}$ and $s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}$. Then, with $y = y(\xi,n) = n\beta+\xi$, we have $$\begin{aligned} _{\uparrow,n} & = \cos(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i (n + 1)\theta} w_{\uparrow}(y+\beta) + \sin(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i (n - 1)\theta} w_{\downarrow}(y-\beta) \\ & = e^{2\pi i n \theta} (\cos(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i \theta} w_{\uparrow}(y+\beta) + \sin(2\pi y) e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_{\downarrow}(y - \beta) )\\ & = e^{2\pi i n\theta} zw_{\uparrow}(y) \\ & = z \varphi_{\uparrow,n} \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $\xi$ by [eq:dual:wup]. Similarly, using [eq:dual:wdown], we have: $$[U^\top_{\beta,\xi} \varphi]_{\downarrow,n} = z \varphi_{\downarrow,n}, \quad \text{a.e.\ } \xi \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Consequently, $U^\top_{\beta,\xi} \varphi^\xi = z \varphi^\xi$ for a.e. $\xi$, as desired. ◻

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
