text:
*Proof of Theorem 5.* Fix $\beta$ and $\theta$. First, let us recast $U\psi = z\psi$ in coordinates by using [eq:ucoord:def]: $$\begin{aligned} z\psi_{\uparrow,n} & = \psi_{\uparrow,n-1} c_{n-1}^{11} + \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} c_{n-1}^{12} \\ z\psi_{\downarrow,n} & = \psi_{\uparrow,n+1} c_{n+1}^{21} + \psi_{\downarrow,n+1} c_{n+1}^{22}. \end{aligned}$$ Multiply both sides (of the first equation) by $e^{2\pi i n x}$, sum over $n \in {\mathbb Z}$, and re-index the sum to get $$\begin{aligned} z \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) & = \sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}} \left( c_{n-1}^{11} \psi_{\uparrow,n-1} + c_{n-1}^{12} \psi_{\downarrow,n-1} \right) e^{2\pi i n x} \\ & = e^{2\pi i x} \sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}} \left(\cos(2\pi(n\beta+\theta)) \psi_{\uparrow,n} - \sin(2\pi(n\beta+\theta)) \psi_{\downarrow,n} \right) e^{2\pi i n x} \end{aligned}$$ for Lebesgue almost-every $x \in {\mathbb T}$. Applying the exponential definitions of the trigonometric functions and the definition of the inverse Fourier transform, the calculation above yields $$\label{eq:psihatupw} z\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) = \frac{e^{2\pi i x}}{2} \left( e^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) - ie^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \right)$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$, where $$w_\uparrow(x) = \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + i \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad w_\downarrow(x) = i\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Similarly, $$\label{eq:psihatdownw} z \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x) = \frac{e^{-2\pi i x}}{2}\left( -ie^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) + e^{-2\pi i \theta}w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \right)$$ for a.e. $x$. Using [eq:psihatupw] and [eq:psihatdownw] in conjunction with the definition of $w$, and the exponential definitions of the trigonometric functions, we get the following for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$: $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:dual:wup} z w_\uparrow(x) = & \cos(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) + \sin(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta), \\ \label{eq:dual:wdown} z w_\downarrow(x) = & - \sin(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) + \cos(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta). \end{aligned}$$ Now, let $\varphi =\varphi^\xi \in {\mathbb C}^{\mathbb Z}\otimes{\mathbb C}^2$ be defined as in the statement of Theorem 5, i.e., $\varphi^\xi_{s,n} = e^{2\pi i n \theta} w_s(n\beta + \xi)$ for $n \in {\mathbb Z}$ and $s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}$. Then, with $y = y(\xi,n) = n\beta+\xi$, we have $$\begin{aligned} _{\uparrow,n} & = \cos(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i (n + 1)\theta} w_{\uparrow}(y+\beta) + \sin(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i (n - 1)\theta} w_{\downarrow}(y-\beta) \\ & = e^{2\pi i n \theta} (\cos(2\pi y) e^{2\pi i \theta} w_{\uparrow}(y+\beta) + \sin(2\pi y) e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_{\downarrow}(y - \beta) )\\ & = e^{2\pi i n\theta} zw_{\uparrow}(y) \\ & = z \varphi_{\uparrow,n} \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $\xi$ by [eq:dual:wup]. Similarly, using [eq:dual:wdown], we have: $$[U^\top_{\beta,\xi} \varphi]_{\downarrow,n} = z \varphi_{\downarrow,n}, \quad \text{a.e.\ } \xi \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Consequently, $U^\top_{\beta,\xi} \varphi^\xi = z \varphi^\xi$ for a.e. $\xi$, as desired. ◻ Notice that our statement of duality differs slightly from the analogous statement for the critical AMO, which is indeed self-dual. Instead, in our setting, $U$ is dual to $U^\top = U^{-1}$. However, the duality between $U$ and $U^{-1}$ is just as useful as the self-duality exploited in the self-adjoint setting. For instance, as is the case for the critical AMO, an immediate consequence of the duality in Theorem 5 is that $U_{\beta,\theta}$ may never have $\ell^1$ eigenfunctions; the companion result for the critical AMO may be found in .
**Corollary 7**. *If $\psi$ is a nonzero solution to $U_{\beta,\theta}\psi = z\psi$ with $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$, then $\psi \notin \ell^1({\mathbb Z},{\mathbb C}^2)$, i.e., $$\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \left( |\psi_{\uparrow,n}| + |\psi_{\downarrow,n}| \right) = \infty.$$*

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text: *Proof.* Suppose on the contrary that $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z\psi$ for some nonzero $\psi \in \ell^1({\mathbb Z},{\mathbb C}^2)$. Then the series which define the inverse Fourier transforms of $\psi_\uparrow$ and $\psi_\downarrow$ converge uniformly on ${\mathbb T}$, so we may follow the argument in the proof of Theorem 5 to see that all of the a.e. statements may be replaced by statements which hold uniformly on ${\mathbb T}$. In particular, we have $U^\top_{\beta,\theta} \varphi^\theta = z \varphi^\theta$. Since $\psi \in \ell^1({\mathbb Z},{\mathbb C}^2) \setminus \{0\}$, $\widecheck\psi_\uparrow$ and $\widecheck\psi_\downarrow$ are continuous and not identically zero; thus, $\varphi$ is bounded and does not go to zero at $\pm \infty$, which is impossible. To see this, notice that the space of solutions to $$\label{eq:geneigeq} U_{\beta,\theta} \eta = z\eta, \quad \eta \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$$ is two-dimensional, so we may choose a second element $\psi' \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ so that $\{\psi,\psi'\}$ spans the space of solutions of [eq:geneigeq]. Since $|\det(M^z(x))| = 1$ for all $x \in {\mathbb T}\setminus\{1/4,3/4\}$, the modulus of the Wronskian of $(\psi_{n+1,\uparrow},\psi_{n,\downarrow})^\top$ and $(\psi'_{n+1,\uparrow},\psi'_{n,\downarrow})^\top$ does not depend on $n$, and hence: $$\lim_{|n|\to \infty} \left\|(\psi'_{n+1,\uparrow}, \psi'_{n,\downarrow})^\top\right\| = \infty.$$ Recall that $U = JC'$ and $U^\top = C'J$, where $J$ and $C'$ are defined by [eq:Jdef] and [eq:Cprimedef], so $U^\top v = zv$ if and only if $v = C'\eta$, where $\eta$ solves [eq:geneigeq]. Thus, since $C'$ is a direct sum of $2 \times 2$ unitary matrices, all solutions of $U_{\beta,\theta}^\top v = zv$ either decay or blow up at $\pm \infty$. However, $\varphi^\theta$ exhibits neither of these behaviors, which is a contradiction. ◻

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text:
*Proof.* Suppose on the contrary that $U_{\beta,\theta} \psi = z\psi$ for some nonzero $\psi \in \ell^1({\mathbb Z},{\mathbb C}^2)$. Then the series which define the inverse Fourier transforms of $\psi_\uparrow$ and $\psi_\downarrow$ converge uniformly on ${\mathbb T}$, so we may follow the argument in the proof of Theorem 5 to see that all of the a.e. statements may be replaced by statements which hold uniformly on ${\mathbb T}$. In particular, we have $U^\top_{\beta,\theta} \varphi^\theta = z \varphi^\theta$. Since $\psi \in \ell^1({\mathbb Z},{\mathbb C}^2) \setminus \{0\}$, $\widecheck\psi_\uparrow$ and $\widecheck\psi_\downarrow$ are continuous and not identically zero; thus, $\varphi$ is bounded and does not go to zero at $\pm \infty$, which is impossible. To see this, notice that the space of solutions to $$\label{eq:geneigeq} U_{\beta,\theta} \eta = z\eta, \quad \eta \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$$ is two-dimensional, so we may choose a second element $\psi' \in {\mathbb C}^{{\mathbb Z}} \otimes {\mathbb C}^2$ so that $\{\psi,\psi'\}$ spans the space of solutions of [eq:geneigeq]. Since $|\det(M^z(x))| = 1$ for all $x \in {\mathbb T}\setminus\{1/4,3/4\}$, the modulus of the Wronskian of $(\psi_{n+1,\uparrow},\psi_{n,\downarrow})^\top$ and $(\psi'_{n+1,\uparrow},\psi'_{n,\downarrow})^\top$ does not depend on $n$, and hence: $$\lim_{|n|\to \infty} \left\|(\psi'_{n+1,\uparrow}, \psi'_{n,\downarrow})^\top\right\| = \infty.$$ Recall that $U = JC'$ and $U^\top = C'J$, where $J$ and $C'$ are defined by [eq:Jdef] and [eq:Cprimedef], so $U^\top v = zv$ if and only if $v = C'\eta$, where $\eta$ solves [eq:geneigeq]. Thus, since $C'$ is a direct sum of $2 \times 2$ unitary matrices, all solutions of $U_{\beta,\theta}^\top v = zv$ either decay or blow up at $\pm \infty$. However, $\varphi^\theta$ exhibits neither of these behaviors, which is a contradiction. ◻
*Proof of Theorem 6.* Let $\mathcal X$ be as in the statement of the Theorem, and notice that ${\mathcal A}$ and $\mathcal X$ commute with one another. Using the factorization $U = JC'$, we obtain a factorization $U_\beta = J C'_\beta$, where $C_\beta'$ and $J$ act on $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ as follows: $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = \psi(n-1,\theta,\downarrow) \\ [J \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) & = \psi(n+1,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [C'_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) & = \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) + \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \\ [C'_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) & = \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) - \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow). \end{aligned}$$ Evidently, $C'_\beta$ and $J$ are real-symmetric, so it follows that $U_\beta^\top = C'_\beta J$.

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text: *Proof of Theorem 6.* Let $\mathcal X$ be as in the statement of the Theorem, and notice that ${\mathcal A}$ and $\mathcal X$ commute with one another. Using the factorization $U = JC'$, we obtain a factorization $U_\beta = J C'_\beta$, where $C_\beta'$ and $J$ act on $\widetilde {\mathcal H}$ as follows: $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = \psi(n-1,\theta,\downarrow) \\ [J \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) & = \psi(n+1,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [C'_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) & = \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) + \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \\ [C'_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) & = \cos(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) - \sin(2\pi(n\beta + \theta)) \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow). \end{aligned}$$ Evidently, $C'_\beta$ and $J$ are real-symmetric, so it follows that $U_\beta^\top = C'_\beta J$. Using the explicit form of $C_\beta'$, one may perform a direct calculation to see that $\mathcal X^* C_\beta' \mathcal X = Q_\beta$, where $$\begin{pmatrix} [Q_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [Q_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \\ e^{2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix}.$$ A similar calculation reveals that $\mathcal X^* Q_\beta^\top \mathcal X = C_\beta'$, as well. Next, we compute $J \mathcal A$. Using the definitions, we have $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = [ {\mathcal A}\psi ](n-1,\theta,\downarrow) \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i m((n-1)\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i (n-1) x} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i m(n\beta+\theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} e^{2\pi i (m\beta + x)} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx. \end{aligned}$$ Consequently, $$[{\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) = e^{2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow).$$ Similarly, one obtains $$[{\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) = e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow).$$ Thus, we obtain ${\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}= Q_\beta^\top$. Similar calculations prove that ${\mathcal A}$ conjugates $Q_\beta$ to $J$. More specifically, we may compute $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = e^{-2\pi i (n\beta+\theta)} [ {\mathcal A}\psi ](n,\theta,\downarrow) \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} e^{- 2\pi i m(n\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{- 2\pi i m(n\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} \psi(m-1,x,\downarrow) \, dx. \end{aligned}$$ Consequently, $[{\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) = \psi(n-1,\theta,\downarrow)$. Similarly, $[{\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) = \psi(n+1,\theta,\uparrow)$. Consequently, ${\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}= J$. Since $\mathcal X$ and $\mathcal A$ commute, it follows that $$\mathcal X^* {\mathcal A}^* U_\beta {\mathcal A}\mathcal X = \mathcal X^* {\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\mathcal X {\mathcal A}^* \mathcal X^* C_\beta'\mathcal X {\mathcal A} = \mathcal X^* Q_\beta^\top \mathcal X {\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A} = C_\beta' J = U_\beta^\top$$ as desired. ◻

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO
text: Using the explicit form of $C_\beta'$, one may perform a direct calculation to see that $\mathcal X^* C_\beta' \mathcal X = Q_\beta$, where $$\begin{pmatrix} [Q_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ [Q_\beta \psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \\ e^{2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow) \\ \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow) \end{pmatrix}.$$ A similar calculation reveals that $\mathcal X^* Q_\beta^\top \mathcal X = C_\beta'$, as well. Next, we compute $J \mathcal A$. Using the definitions, we have $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = [ {\mathcal A}\psi ](n-1,\theta,\downarrow) \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i m((n-1)\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i (n-1) x} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i m(n\beta+\theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} e^{2\pi i (m\beta + x)} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx. \end{aligned}$$ Consequently, $$[{\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) = e^{2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \psi(n,\theta,\downarrow).$$ Similarly, one obtains $$[{\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) = e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} \psi(n,\theta,\uparrow).$$ Thus, we obtain ${\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}= Q_\beta^\top$. Similar calculations prove that ${\mathcal A}$ conjugates $Q_\beta$ to $J$. More specifically, we may compute $$\begin{aligned} (n,\theta,\uparrow) & = e^{-2\pi i (n\beta+\theta)} [ {\mathcal A}\psi ](n,\theta,\downarrow) \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{-2\pi i (n\beta + \theta)} e^{- 2\pi i m(n\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} \psi(m,x,\downarrow) \, dx \\ & = \sum_{m \in {\mathbb Z}} \int_{{\mathbb T}} \! e^{- 2\pi i m(n\beta + \theta)} e^{-2\pi i n x} \psi(m-1,x,\downarrow) \, dx. \end{aligned}$$ Consequently, $[{\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\uparrow) = \psi(n-1,\theta,\downarrow)$. Similarly, $[{\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}\psi](n,\theta,\downarrow) = \psi(n+1,\theta,\uparrow)$. Consequently, ${\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A}= J$. Since $\mathcal X$ and $\mathcal A$ commute, it follows that $$\mathcal X^* {\mathcal A}^* U_\beta {\mathcal A}\mathcal X = \mathcal X^* {\mathcal A}^* J {\mathcal A}\mathcal X {\mathcal A}^* \mathcal X^* C_\beta'\mathcal X {\mathcal A} = \mathcal X^* Q_\beta^\top \mathcal X {\mathcal A}^* Q_\beta {\mathcal A} = C_\beta' J = U_\beta^\top$$ as desired. ◻

heading.title: Aubry Duality for the Unitary AMO

section_path: The Spectral Type
text:
# The Spectral Type As a pleasant consequence of the duality described in Theorem 5, let us see how it may be used to deduce absence of point spectrum for almost all parameters. Specifically, we will show that the unitary AMO has no point spectrum for all irrational $\beta$ and then for almost every $\theta$. Let us begin by proving that the spectral type of $U_{\beta,\theta}$ is always purely singular. This is a standard “high-barrier” argument using results of trace-class scattering theory.
*Proof of Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:singspec].* Since $\beta$ is irrational, we may choose integers $n_j \in {\mathbb Z}$ with $\cdots < n_{-1} < n_0 < n_1 < \cdots$ so that $|c_{n_j}^{11}| = |\cos(2\pi(n_j\beta+\theta))| < 2^{-|j|}$ for all $j \in {\mathbb Z}$. Consequently, it is not hard to see that $U_{\beta,\theta}$ is a trace-class perturbation of the quantum walk update rule $\widetilde U$ given by decoupling at sites in the set $\{ n_j : j \in {\mathbb Z}\}$. Concretely, $\widetilde U$ is given by specifying coins $$\widetilde C_{n_j} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -{\mathrm{sgn}}(\sin(2\pi(n_j\beta + \theta))) \\ {\mathrm{sgn}}(\sin(2\pi(n_j\beta + \theta))) & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \quad j \in {\mathbb Z},$$ and $\widetilde C_n = C_n = R_{2\pi(n\beta+\theta)}$ for all other values of $n$. Evidently, $\widetilde U$ is a direct sum of finite-dimensional operators; consequently, $\widetilde U$ has no a.c. spectrum. Since trace-class perturbations leave a.c. spectrum invariant, the a.c. spectrum of $U$ is empty; see, e.g., . ◻

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text:
As we proceed with the argument which excludes eigenvalues, we will need to pass between the cocycles $M^z$ and $N^z$ defined by [eq:tmdef] and [eq:tmNdef]. Clearly, to relate these objects, one must have fine control over products of the form $$\label{eq:cosproddef} 2^k\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}|\cos[2\pi(\theta+j\beta)]|.$$ For example, using the Birkhorff ergodic theorem and formula [eq:logcosint] below, one may conclude that $$\lim_{k \to \infty} \frac1k\log\left( 2^k\prod_{j=0}^{k-1}|\cos[2\pi(\theta+j\beta)]| \right) = 0,$$ for almost every $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$ by ergodicity of $x \mapsto \theta+\beta$. However, this yields rather poor control over the product in [eq:cosproddef], so one must go beyond the ergodic theorem. Thus, the following proposition (which is ) is essential to our arguments.
**Proposition 8**. *Let $f:{\mathbb T}\rightarrow{\mathbb C}$ be analytic and $\beta$ a fixed irrational number. Let $\{\frac{p_n}{q_n}\}_{n\in{\mathbb Z}_+}$ be the continued fraction approximants of $\beta$. Then there exists a constant $C = C(\beta) > 0$ and a subsequence $(q_{n_l})$ of $(q_n)$ such that $$\sum^{q_{n_l}-1}_{j=0}\log|f(\theta+j\beta)|-q_{n_l}\int_{\mathbb T}\log|f(x)| \, dx \le C$$ uniformly in $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$.*
In particular, this proposition yields the following corollary immediately.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: **Corollary 9**. *Let $\beta\notin{\mathbb Q}$ be as in Propostion 8. Then there is a $C_0>0$ and a subsequence $(q_{n_l})$ of $(q_n)$ such that $$\label{eq:subharmonic:prod1} 2^{q_{n_l}}\prod^{q_{n_l}-1}_{j=0}\left|\cos[2\pi(\theta+j\beta)]\right|\le C_0$$ uniformly in $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$. Consequently, we obtain for any $r\in{\mathbb Z}_+$, $$\label{eq:subharmonic:prod2} 2^{rq_{n_l}}\prod^{rq_{n_l}-1}_{j=0}\left|\cos[2\pi(\theta+j\beta)]\right|\le C^r_0$$ uniformly in $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$.*

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: *Proof.* First, we compute that for ${\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$, $$\label{eq:logcosint} \int_{{\mathbb T}}\log|\cos2\pi (\theta+i{\varepsilon})| \, dx = 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|-\log2.$$ For the proof of the present corollary, we only need the case ${\varepsilon}=0$. However, we will need [eq:logcosint] for ${\varepsilon}\in{\mathbb R}$ in Section 5. The argument follows and is given for the convenience of the reader. We first consider the case ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$. Let $\Gamma$ be the rectanglular contour with vertices $0$, $\pi$, $\pi+i{\varepsilon}$, and $i{\varepsilon}$, oriented counterclockwise. Let $\zeta=\theta+i{\varepsilon}$. It is clear that $$h(\zeta) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= \log(1-e^{2i \zeta}) = \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta)$$ is analytic on the closed region enclosed by $\Gamma$ except at $\zeta= 0, \pi$. However, by following small circular quadrants around $0$ and $\pi$ and letting the radii of these circles go to zero, we obtain $$\int_{\Gamma} \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta) \, d\zeta = 0$$ by Cauchy’s Theorem. Since the integrand has period $\pi$, the integrals over the vertical edges of $\Gamma$ cancel one another. The integral over the upper horizontal side tends to $0$ as ${\varepsilon}\rightarrow\infty$. Hence we first get $\int^\pi_0 \log(-2ie^{i\theta}\sin \theta) \, d\theta = 0$, which in turn implies that for all ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$, $$\int^{\pi+i{\varepsilon}}_{i{\varepsilon}} \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta) \,d\zeta = \int^{\pi}_{0} \log[-2ie^{i(\theta+i{\varepsilon})}\sin (\theta+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta=0.$$ Thus, $$\pi \log2 -\frac{\pi^2}{2}i +\frac{\pi^2}{2}i -\pi{\varepsilon} +\int^\pi_0\log[\sin(x+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta = 0,$$ which clearly implies $$\int^\pi_0\log[\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta = \pi{\varepsilon}-\pi\log2=\int^\pi_0\log|\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})| \, d\theta,$$ where the last equality follows from $\int^\pi_0\log|\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})|d\theta=\mathrm{Re} \, \int^\pi_0\log[\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})]\, d\theta$.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: *Proof.* First, we compute that for ${\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$, $$\label{eq:logcosint} \int_{{\mathbb T}}\log|\cos2\pi (\theta+i{\varepsilon})| \, dx = 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|-\log2.$$ For the proof of the present corollary, we only need the case ${\varepsilon}=0$. However, we will need [eq:logcosint] for ${\varepsilon}\in{\mathbb R}$ in Section 5. The argument follows and is given for the convenience of the reader. We first consider the case ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$. Let $\Gamma$ be the rectanglular contour with vertices $0$, $\pi$, $\pi+i{\varepsilon}$, and $i{\varepsilon}$, oriented counterclockwise. Let $\zeta=\theta+i{\varepsilon}$. It is clear that $$h(\zeta) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= \log(1-e^{2i \zeta}) = \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta)$$ is analytic on the closed region enclosed by $\Gamma$ except at $\zeta= 0, \pi$. However, by following small circular quadrants around $0$ and $\pi$ and letting the radii of these circles go to zero, we obtain $$\int_{\Gamma} \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta) \, d\zeta = 0$$ by Cauchy’s Theorem. Since the integrand has period $\pi$, the integrals over the vertical edges of $\Gamma$ cancel one another. The integral over the upper horizontal side tends to $0$ as ${\varepsilon}\rightarrow\infty$. Hence we first get $\int^\pi_0 \log(-2ie^{i\theta}\sin \theta) \, d\theta = 0$, which in turn implies that for all ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$, $$\int^{\pi+i{\varepsilon}}_{i{\varepsilon}} \log(-2ie^{i\zeta}\sin \zeta) \,d\zeta = \int^{\pi}_{0} \log[-2ie^{i(\theta+i{\varepsilon})}\sin (\theta+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta=0.$$ Thus, $$\pi \log2 -\frac{\pi^2}{2}i +\frac{\pi^2}{2}i -\pi{\varepsilon} +\int^\pi_0\log[\sin(x+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta = 0,$$ which clearly implies $$\int^\pi_0\log[\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})] \, d\theta = \pi{\varepsilon}-\pi\log2=\int^\pi_0\log|\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})| \, d\theta,$$ where the last equality follows from $\int^\pi_0\log|\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})|d\theta=\mathrm{Re} \, \int^\pi_0\log[\sin(\theta+i{\varepsilon})]\, d\theta$. Then by a simple change of variables, we obtain the following for all ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$: $$\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathbb T}\log|\cos(2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon}))| \, d\theta &= \int_{\mathbb T}\log|\sin(2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon}))| \, d\theta\\ &= \frac1\pi\int^\pi_0\log |\sin(\theta+i2\pi{\varepsilon})| \, d\theta\\ &= 2\pi{\varepsilon}-\log2. \end{aligned}$$ Since $\cos2\pi(\theta-i{\varepsilon})=\overline{\cos2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon})}$ for all $\theta,{\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$, we obtain [eq:logcosint] for all ${\varepsilon}\in{\mathbb R}$.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: Then by a simple change of variables, we obtain the following for all ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$: $$\begin{aligned} \int_{\mathbb T}\log|\cos(2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon}))| \, d\theta &= \int_{\mathbb T}\log|\sin(2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon}))| \, d\theta\\ &= \frac1\pi\int^\pi_0\log |\sin(\theta+i2\pi{\varepsilon})| \, d\theta\\ &= 2\pi{\varepsilon}-\log2. \end{aligned}$$ Since $\cos2\pi(\theta-i{\varepsilon})=\overline{\cos2\pi(\theta+i{\varepsilon})}$ for all $\theta,{\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$, we obtain [eq:logcosint] for all ${\varepsilon}\in{\mathbb R}$. Now let $f(\theta)=\cos(2\pi \theta)$, and choose $n_l$ as in Proposition 8. Using Proposition 8 and the ${\varepsilon}= 0$ case of [eq:logcosint] we have $$\label{eq:subharmonic:sum2} q_{n_l}\log 2 + \sum_{j=0}^{q_{n_l}-1} \log|\cos(2\pi(\theta+j\beta))| \le C$$ for all $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$. Let $C_0=e^{C}$. By exponentiating both sides of [eq:subharmonic:sum2], we then obtain [eq:subharmonic:prod1]. Let $g(x)$ be the right-hand side of [eq:subharmonic:prod1], and $g_r(\theta)$ be right-hand side of [eq:subharmonic:prod2]. By the uniformity of the estimate [eq:subharmonic:prod1] in $x\in{\mathbb T}$, we obtain $$g_r(\theta)=\prod^{r-1}_{j=0}g(\theta+jq_{n_l}) < C_0^r$$ uniformly in $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$, which is nothing other than [eq:subharmonic:prod2]. ◻ Finally we need the following Lemma.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text:
**Lemma 10**. *Let $\mathbf k=\{k_n\}\subset{\mathbb Z}_+$ be an arbitrary sequence of positive integers such that $\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}k_n=\infty$, and let $\|\cdot\|_{{\mathbb R}/{\mathbb Z}}$ denote the distance to the nearest integer. For each pair $l, m\in{\mathbb Z}_+$, set $E_{m,l}=\{\theta\in{\mathbb T}: \|k_l\theta\|_{{\mathbb R}/{\mathbb Z}}<\frac 1{4m}\}$. Then the following set has zero Lebesgue measure: $$E(\mathbf k):=\bigcap_{m\in{\mathbb Z}_+}\bigcup_{N\in{\mathbb Z}_+}\bigcap_{l\ge N}E_{m,l}.$$*
*Proof.* Let $\mu$ denote normalized Lebesgue measure on ${\mathbb T}$. First, it is clear that $\mu(E_{m,l})=\frac 1{2m}$ for each $m, l\in{\mathbb Z}_+$. Moreover, $E(\mathbf k)\subset \bigcup_{N\in{\mathbb Z}_+}\bigcap_{l\ge N}E_{m,l}$ for all $m,l$. Since $$\mu\left(\bigcup_{N\in{\mathbb Z}_+}\bigcap_{l\ge N}E_{m,l}\right)=\lim_{N\rightarrow\infty}\mu\left(\bigcap_{l\ge N}E_{m,l}\right)\le \frac 1{2m}$$ for each $m\in{\mathbb Z}_+$, it follows that $$\mu(E(\mathbf k))\le \mu\left(\bigcup_{N\in{\mathbb Z}_+}\bigcap_{l\ge N}E_{m,l}\right)\le \frac 1{2m}.$$ Since this holds for all $m \in {\mathbb Z}_+$, $\mu (E(\mathbf k))=0$. ◻
**Definition 1**. Given $\beta \in {\mathbb T}\setminus {\mathbb Q}$, let $q_{n_l}$ be as in Proposition 8, and denote $\mathbf k = \{4q_{n_l}\}_{l =1}^\infty$ and $E = E(\mathbf k)$ as in Lemma 10. Define the set $\mathcal S_\beta$ by $$\mathcal S_{\beta} = \left\{\frac l2 + \frac{k\beta}{2}:\ k, l\in{\mathbb Z}\right\}\bigcup E(\mathbf k).$$

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text:
Of course, $\mu(S_\beta)=0$ since it is the union of a zero-measure set and a countable set. We are now in a position to prove Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:contspec]. Clearly, this will follow from the following theorem:
**Theorem 11**. *If $\beta$ is irrational and $\theta \notin \mathcal S_\beta$, then $\sigma_{{\mathrm{pp}}}(U_{\beta,\theta}) = \emptyset$.*

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: *Proof.* Singularity of the cocycle map $N^z$ and the different form of self-duality complicate matters considerably and force us to do substantial additional work, but our proof follows the outline of an argument of Avila . Let $\beta$ and $\theta$ be as stated, abbreviate $U = U_{\beta, \theta}$, and adopt the same notation as the proof of Theorem 5. Suppose for the sake of establishing a contradiction that $\sigma_{{\mathrm{pp}}}(U_{\beta,\theta}) \neq \emptyset$, and let $0 \neq \psi \in {\mathcal H}$ and $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ be such that $U \psi = z \psi$. As before, we view $\psi \in {\mathcal H}$ as a pair of $\ell^2$ sequences $\psi_\uparrow = (\psi_{\uparrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ and $\psi_\downarrow = (\psi_{\downarrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$. Let $$\widecheck\psi_\uparrow(x)=\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \psi_{\uparrow,n} e^{2\pi inx}, \quad \widecheck\psi_\downarrow(x)=\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \psi_{\downarrow,n} e^{2\pi inx}$$ be the inverse Fourier Transforms of $\psi_\uparrow$ and $\psi_\downarrow$, respectively, and define $w_\uparrow$ and $w_\downarrow$ as in Section 3, i.e., $$w_\uparrow(x) = \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + i \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad w_\downarrow(x) = i\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x).$$ Since $\psi_s \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ for $s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$, it follows that $\widecheck\psi_s$ and $w_s$ are in $L^2({\mathbb T})$. From the proof of Theorem 5, we recall [eq:dual:wup] and [eq:dual:wdown], which read: $$\begin{aligned} z w_\uparrow(x) = & \sin(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta) + \cos(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta), \\ z w_\downarrow(x) = & \cos(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta) - \sin(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$. We may rephrase these identities to see that the cocycle which propagates solution data is semi-conjugate to a diagonal cocycle. More precisely, we may rearrange to [eq:dual:wup] and [eq:dual:wdown] to see that $$\label{eq:w:cocycleconj} M^z(x) \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \\ w_\uparrow(x) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} w_\downarrow(x) \\ e^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) \end{pmatrix}$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$, where $M^z(x)$ is as defined in [eq:tmdef]. Next, since $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ (by assumption), we have $\bar z = z^{-1}$. Using this, [eq:dual:wup], and [eq:dual:wdown], we also have $$\label{eq:w:cocycleconj2} M^z(x) \begin{pmatrix} \bar{w}_\uparrow(x) \\ e^{2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\downarrow(x - \beta) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\uparrow(x+\beta) \\ \bar{w}_\downarrow(x) \end{pmatrix}$$ for a.e. $x$. Combining [eq:w:cocycleconj] and [eq:w:cocycleconj2], we obtain $$\label{semi-conjugacy} M^z(x) B(x) = B(x + \beta) D_\theta \text{ for a.e. } x \in {\mathbb T},$$ where $$B(x) = \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) & \bar{w}_\uparrow(x) \\ w_\uparrow(x) & e^{2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\downarrow(x-\beta) \end{pmatrix}, \quad D_\theta = \begin{pmatrix} e^{2\pi i \theta} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{-2\pi i \theta} \end{pmatrix}.$$

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: *Proof.* Singularity of the cocycle map $N^z$ and the different form of self-duality complicate matters considerably and force us to do substantial additional work, but our proof follows the outline of an argument of Avila . Let $\beta$ and $\theta$ be as stated, abbreviate $U = U_{\beta, \theta}$, and adopt the same notation as the proof of Theorem 5. Suppose for the sake of establishing a contradiction that $\sigma_{{\mathrm{pp}}}(U_{\beta,\theta}) \neq \emptyset$, and let $0 \neq \psi \in {\mathcal H}$ and $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ be such that $U \psi = z \psi$. As before, we view $\psi \in {\mathcal H}$ as a pair of $\ell^2$ sequences $\psi_\uparrow = (\psi_{\uparrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$ and $\psi_\downarrow = (\psi_{\downarrow,n})_{n \in {\mathbb Z}}$. Let $$\widecheck\psi_\uparrow(x)=\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \psi_{\uparrow,n} e^{2\pi inx}, \quad \widecheck\psi_\downarrow(x)=\sum_{n \in {\mathbb Z}} \psi_{\downarrow,n} e^{2\pi inx}$$ be the inverse Fourier Transforms of $\psi_\uparrow$ and $\psi_\downarrow$, respectively, and define $w_\uparrow$ and $w_\downarrow$ as in Section 3, i.e., $$w_\uparrow(x) = \widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + i \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x), \quad w_\downarrow(x) = i\widecheck \psi_\uparrow(x) + \widecheck \psi_\downarrow(x).$$ Since $\psi_s \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ for $s \in \{\uparrow, \downarrow\}$, it follows that $\widecheck\psi_s$ and $w_s$ are in $L^2({\mathbb T})$. From the proof of Theorem 5, we recall [eq:dual:wup] and [eq:dual:wdown], which read: $$\begin{aligned} z w_\uparrow(x) = & \sin(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta) + \cos(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta), \\ z w_\downarrow(x) = & \cos(2 \pi x)e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x - \beta) - \sin(2 \pi x) e^{ 2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x + \beta) \end{aligned}$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$. We may rephrase these identities to see that the cocycle which propagates solution data is semi-conjugate to a diagonal cocycle. More precisely, we may rearrange to [eq:dual:wup] and [eq:dual:wdown] to see that $$\label{eq:w:cocycleconj} M^z(x) \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) \\ w_\uparrow(x) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} w_\downarrow(x) \\ e^{2\pi i \theta} w_\uparrow(x+\beta) \end{pmatrix}$$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$, where $M^z(x)$ is as defined in [eq:tmdef]. Next, since $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ (by assumption), we have $\bar z = z^{-1}$. Using this, [eq:dual:wup], and [eq:dual:wdown], we also have $$\label{eq:w:cocycleconj2} M^z(x) \begin{pmatrix} \bar{w}_\uparrow(x) \\ e^{2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\downarrow(x - \beta) \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\uparrow(x+\beta) \\ \bar{w}_\downarrow(x) \end{pmatrix}$$ for a.e. $x$. Combining [eq:w:cocycleconj] and [eq:w:cocycleconj2], we obtain $$\label{semi-conjugacy} M^z(x) B(x) = B(x + \beta) D_\theta \text{ for a.e. } x \in {\mathbb T},$$ where $$B(x) = \begin{pmatrix} e^{-2\pi i \theta} w_\downarrow(x-\beta) & \bar{w}_\uparrow(x) \\ w_\uparrow(x) & e^{2\pi i \theta} \bar{w}_\downarrow(x-\beta) \end{pmatrix}, \quad D_\theta = \begin{pmatrix} e^{2\pi i \theta} & 0 \\ 0 & e^{-2\pi i \theta} \end{pmatrix}.$$ By taking the determinant of both sides, [semi-conjugacy] implies that $\det B(x+\beta) = \det B(x)$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$. Since $\det(B(\cdot)) \in L^1({\mathbb T})$, ergodicity of $x\mapsto x+\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ implies that $\det B(x)$ is constant almost everywhere; we denote this constant value by $\det(B)$. Equation [semi-conjugacy] implies that the set $\{x: B(x) = 0\}$ is invariant under $x\mapsto x+\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ as well. Thus, we must have $\|B(x)\|>0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$. For, if not, then $\|B(x)\|=0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$, which implies $\psi=0$, contrary to our assumption thereupon.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: By taking the determinant of both sides, [semi-conjugacy] implies that $\det B(x+\beta) = \det B(x)$ for a.e. $x \in {\mathbb T}$. Since $\det(B(\cdot)) \in L^1({\mathbb T})$, ergodicity of $x\mapsto x+\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ implies that $\det B(x)$ is constant almost everywhere; we denote this constant value by $\det(B)$. Equation [semi-conjugacy] implies that the set $\{x: B(x) = 0\}$ is invariant under $x\mapsto x+\beta$ on ${\mathbb T}$ as well. Thus, we must have $\|B(x)\|>0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$. For, if not, then $\|B(x)\|=0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$, which implies $\psi=0$, contrary to our assumption thereupon. Let us show how the assumption $\theta \notin \mathcal S_\beta$ yields $\det B\neq 0$. Indeed, $\det B(x)=0$ gives $$|w_\downarrow(x-\beta)|^2 - |w_\uparrow(x)|^2=0 \text{ for a.e.\ } x\in {\mathbb T}.$$ Hence, there exists a $\phi(x)$ with $|\phi(x)|=1$ for all $x\in{\mathbb T}$ such that $$w_\uparrow(x) = \phi(x)e^{2 \pi i \theta} \bar w_\downarrow(x - \beta) \text{ for a.e.\ } x\in{\mathbb T}.$$ If we write $B(x)=(\vec u(x), \vec v(x))$ where $\vec u(x)$ and $\vec v(x)$ are column vectors, then one readily checks that $\vec u(x)=\phi(x) \vec v(x)$. Hence, [semi-conjugacy] implies $$M(x)\vec u(x) = e^{2\pi i \theta} \vec u(x+\beta), \quad M(x) \phi(x)\vec u(x) = e^{-2\pi i \theta} \phi(x+\beta) \vec u(x+\beta)$$ for a.e. $x$. Since $z$ is fixed, we have dropped it from the notation in the equation above and in the remainder of the argument. Clearly, the above equalities imply $$\phi(x+\beta) = e^{4\pi i \theta} \phi(x) \text{ for a.e. } x\in{\mathbb T}.$$ Now, if we consider the Fourier Transform of $\phi$, defined by [eq:ftdef], we have $\phi(x) = \sum_k \widehat\phi_k e^{2\pi i k x}$ (a.e. $x$). Thus, we obtain $$e^{2\pi ik\beta}\widehat \phi_k = e^{4\pi i\theta} \widehat \phi_k \text{ for all } k\in{\mathbb Z}.$$ $\theta\notin \mathcal S_\beta$ implies $e^{2\pi ik\beta}\neq e^{4\pi i\theta}$ for all $k\in{\mathbb Z}$. Hence $\widehat \phi_k=0$ for all $k$, which forces $\phi(x)=0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$, contrary to our assumption that $|\phi(x)|=1$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: Let us show how the assumption $\theta \notin \mathcal S_\beta$ yields $\det B\neq 0$. Indeed, $\det B(x)=0$ gives $$|w_\downarrow(x-\beta)|^2 - |w_\uparrow(x)|^2=0 \text{ for a.e.\ } x\in {\mathbb T}.$$ Hence, there exists a $\phi(x)$ with $|\phi(x)|=1$ for all $x\in{\mathbb T}$ such that $$w_\uparrow(x) = \phi(x)e^{2 \pi i \theta} \bar w_\downarrow(x - \beta) \text{ for a.e.\ } x\in{\mathbb T}.$$ If we write $B(x)=(\vec u(x), \vec v(x))$ where $\vec u(x)$ and $\vec v(x)$ are column vectors, then one readily checks that $\vec u(x)=\phi(x) \vec v(x)$. Hence, [semi-conjugacy] implies $$M(x)\vec u(x) = e^{2\pi i \theta} \vec u(x+\beta), \quad M(x) \phi(x)\vec u(x) = e^{-2\pi i \theta} \phi(x+\beta) \vec u(x+\beta)$$ for a.e. $x$. Since $z$ is fixed, we have dropped it from the notation in the equation above and in the remainder of the argument. Clearly, the above equalities imply $$\phi(x+\beta) = e^{4\pi i \theta} \phi(x) \text{ for a.e. } x\in{\mathbb T}.$$ Now, if we consider the Fourier Transform of $\phi$, defined by [eq:ftdef], we have $\phi(x) = \sum_k \widehat\phi_k e^{2\pi i k x}$ (a.e. $x$). Thus, we obtain $$e^{2\pi ik\beta}\widehat \phi_k = e^{4\pi i\theta} \widehat \phi_k \text{ for all } k\in{\mathbb Z}.$$ $\theta\notin \mathcal S_\beta$ implies $e^{2\pi ik\beta}\neq e^{4\pi i\theta}$ for all $k\in{\mathbb Z}$. Hence $\widehat \phi_k=0$ for all $k$, which forces $\phi(x)=0$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$, contrary to our assumption that $|\phi(x)|=1$ for a.e. $x\in{\mathbb T}$. Thus, the semi-conjugacy [semi-conjugacy] becomes a $L^2$ conjugacy between $M(x)$ and the constant diagonal matrix $D_\theta$, to wit: $$\label{conjugacy} M(x) = B(x+\beta)D_\theta B(x)^{-1}, \quad \text{a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Now, with $M_k(x)=M(x+(k-1)\beta)\cdots M(x)$ for $k \in {\mathbb Z}_+$ and $x \in {\mathbb T}$, [conjugacy] gives $$M_k(x) = B(x+k\beta)D^kB(x)^{-1} \quad \text{for all } k \in {\mathbb Z}_+ \text{ and a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Let $\Phi_k(x)=\mathrm{tr} (M_k(x))-2\cos2\pi k\theta$, where $\mathrm{tr} ( A)$ denotes the trace of the matrix $A$. By cyclicity of the trace, we obtain $$\Phi_k(x) = \mathrm{tr} \left( B(x+k\beta)D^kB(x)^{-1} \right) - \mathrm{tr} \left( B(x)D^kB(x)^{-1} \right), \quad \forall k \in {\mathbb Z}_+, \text{ a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Since $\|A^{-1}\|=\frac{\|A\|}{\det(A)}$ for any invertible $2 \times 2$ matrix $A$, and $|\mathrm{tr} (E)|\le 2\|E\|$ for any $2\times 2$ matrix $E$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} |\Phi_k(x)| &= \left|\mathrm{tr} \left(B(x+k\beta)-B(x))D^kB(x)^{-1} \right)\right|\\ &\le 2 \| (B(x+k\beta)-B(x))D^kB(x)^{-1} \| \\ & \le \frac{2}{|\det B|}\|B(x+k\beta)-B(x)\|\cdot \|B(x)\|. \end{aligned}$$ Since $\psi_s \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ for $s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}$, it is also clear that $\|B(x)\|\in L^2({\mathbb T})$. Thus, by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we obtain $$\label{trace:estimate} \|\Phi_k\|^2_{L^1} \le \frac{4}{|\det(B)|^2}\int_{\mathbb T}\|B(x+k\beta)-B(x)\|^2 \, dx \cdot \int_{\mathbb T}\|B(x)\|^2 \, dx.$$ Note that for any $g\in L^2({\mathbb T})$, by Parseval’s identity, it holds that $$\label{L2norm:estimate} \lim_{{\varepsilon}\rightarrow 0}\|g(\cdot+{\varepsilon})-g\|^2_{L^2} = \lim_{{\varepsilon}\rightarrow 0}\sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}}|\hat g_n|^2|e^{-2\pi{\varepsilon}ni}-1|^2=0.$$ Note also for any $2\times 2$ matrix $E=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}a&b\\c&d\end{smallmatrix}\right)$, it holds that $\|E\|\le \|E\|_{\mathrm{HS}}$, where $$\|E\|_{\mathrm{HS}} = \sqrt{|a|^2+|b|^2+|c|^2+|d|^2}$$ is the Hilbert-Schmidt norm.

heading.title: The Spectral Type

section_path: The Spectral Type
text: Thus, the semi-conjugacy [semi-conjugacy] becomes a $L^2$ conjugacy between $M(x)$ and the constant diagonal matrix $D_\theta$, to wit: $$\label{conjugacy} M(x) = B(x+\beta)D_\theta B(x)^{-1}, \quad \text{a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Now, with $M_k(x)=M(x+(k-1)\beta)\cdots M(x)$ for $k \in {\mathbb Z}_+$ and $x \in {\mathbb T}$, [conjugacy] gives $$M_k(x) = B(x+k\beta)D^kB(x)^{-1} \quad \text{for all } k \in {\mathbb Z}_+ \text{ and a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Let $\Phi_k(x)=\mathrm{tr} (M_k(x))-2\cos2\pi k\theta$, where $\mathrm{tr} ( A)$ denotes the trace of the matrix $A$. By cyclicity of the trace, we obtain $$\Phi_k(x) = \mathrm{tr} \left( B(x+k\beta)D^kB(x)^{-1} \right) - \mathrm{tr} \left( B(x)D^kB(x)^{-1} \right), \quad \forall k \in {\mathbb Z}_+, \text{ a.e.\ } x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Since $\|A^{-1}\|=\frac{\|A\|}{\det(A)}$ for any invertible $2 \times 2$ matrix $A$, and $|\mathrm{tr} (E)|\le 2\|E\|$ for any $2\times 2$ matrix $E$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned} |\Phi_k(x)| &= \left|\mathrm{tr} \left(B(x+k\beta)-B(x))D^kB(x)^{-1} \right)\right|\\ &\le 2 \| (B(x+k\beta)-B(x))D^kB(x)^{-1} \| \\ & \le \frac{2}{|\det B|}\|B(x+k\beta)-B(x)\|\cdot \|B(x)\|. \end{aligned}$$ Since $\psi_s \in \ell^2({\mathbb Z})$ for $s \in \{\uparrow,\downarrow\}$, it is also clear that $\|B(x)\|\in L^2({\mathbb T})$. Thus, by the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we obtain $$\label{trace:estimate} \|\Phi_k\|^2_{L^1} \le \frac{4}{|\det(B)|^2}\int_{\mathbb T}\|B(x+k\beta)-B(x)\|^2 \, dx \cdot \int_{\mathbb T}\|B(x)\|^2 \, dx.$$ Note that for any $g\in L^2({\mathbb T})$, by Parseval’s identity, it holds that $$\label{L2norm:estimate} \lim_{{\varepsilon}\rightarrow 0}\|g(\cdot+{\varepsilon})-g\|^2_{L^2} = \lim_{{\varepsilon}\rightarrow 0}\sum_{n\in{\mathbb Z}}|\hat g_n|^2|e^{-2\pi{\varepsilon}ni}-1|^2=0.$$ Note also for any $2\times 2$ matrix $E=\left(\begin{smallmatrix}a&b\\c&d\end{smallmatrix}\right)$, it holds that $\|E\|\le \|E\|_{\mathrm{HS}}$, where $$\|E\|_{\mathrm{HS}} = \sqrt{|a|^2+|b|^2+|c|^2+|d|^2}$$ is the Hilbert-Schmidt norm. Now by taking any sequence $k_n \in {\mathbb Z}$ such that $\lim_{n\to\infty}\|k_n\beta\|_{{\mathbb R}/{\mathbb Z}}=0$, passing to the Hilbert-Schmidt norm, and using [L2norm:estimate], one readily checks that $$\label{eq:L1:liminf0} \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\int_{\mathbb T}\|B(x+k_n\beta)-B(x)\|^2 \, dx = 0.$$ In particular, one may take $k_n=4q_n$, where $q_n$ is the denominator of the continued fraction approximants of $\beta$. Hence, [trace:estimate] and [eq:L1:liminf0] imply that $$\label{eq:traceL1decay} \lim_{n \to \infty} \| \Phi_{4q_n} \|_{L^1} = 0.$$ Now, we will use $N$, defined by [eq:tmNdef]. Evidently, we can rewrite $N$ as follows: $$\begin{aligned} \label{trace:extremalcoefficient} N(x) & = \begin{pmatrix}-2iz^{-1} & e^{2\pi i x}-e^{-2\pi i x}\\ e^{2\pi i x}-e^{-2\pi i x} & -2iz \end{pmatrix},\quad x \in {\mathbb T}, \; z \in {\mathbb C}\setminus \{0\}.. \end{aligned}$$ A direct computation shows that $$\label{trouble} \Phi_k(x)=\mathrm{tr} M_k(x)-2\cos(2\pi k\theta) = \frac{\mathrm{tr} N_k(x)}{(-2i)^k}\prod^{k-1}_{j=0}\sec[2\pi (x+j\beta)]-2\cos(2\pi k\theta).$$ Let $$f_k(x) = (-2i)^k\prod^{k-1}_{j=0}\cos[2\pi (x+j\beta)], \quad k \in {\mathbb Z}_+, \; x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ Then, [trouble] gives $$\label{trouble2} f_k(x)\Phi_k(x)=\mathrm{tr} N_k(x)-2\cos(2\pi k\theta)f_k(x), \text{ for all } k \in {\mathbb Z}_+, \; x \in {\mathbb T}.$$ First, by a straightforward computation, we notice that $\mathrm{tr} (N_k(x))$ is a trigonometric polynomial of the form $$\mathrm{tr} (N_k(x)) = \sum^{k}_{j=-k}c_n e^{2\pi ijx}.$$ For $k \in 2{\mathbb Z}_+$, one readily checks that the extremal Fourier coefficient is given by $$c_k=2e^{\pi ik(k-1)\beta}.$$ It is clear that $f_k(x)$ is trigonometric polynomial of degree $k$ as well. Moreover, the extremal Fourier coefficient of $f_k(x)$ is $e^{\pi ik(k-1)\beta}$ whenever $k\in 4{\mathbb Z}_+$. Hence, for any $k \in 4{\mathbb Z}_+$, we obtain for the right hand side of [trouble2]: $$\begin{aligned} \|\mathrm{tr} N_k - 2\cos(2\pi k\theta)f_k\|_{L^1} & \ge \left|\int_{\mathbb T}\left(\mathrm{tr} N_k(x)-2\cos(2\pi k\theta)f_k(x)\right)e^{-2\pi ikx} \, dx\right|\\ &= \left|2e^{\pi ik(k-1)\beta}- 2\cos(2\pi k\theta)e^{\pi ik(k-1)\beta}\right|\\ &= 2-2\cos(2\pi k\theta). \end{aligned}$$ Now, since $\theta\not\in E(\mathbf k)$ where $\mathbf k=\{4q_{n_l}\}^\infty_{l=1}$, we may choose $m\in{\mathbb Z}_+$ and a subsequence $(k_s)_{s\in{\mathbb Z}_+}$ of $(4q_{n_l})$ such that $$\left\|k_s\theta\right\|_{{\mathbb R}/{\mathbb Z}}>\frac1{4m}.$$ Let $c = 2-2\cos(\frac1{4m})>0$. Then for each $s\in{\mathbb Z}_+$, it holds that $$\label{right:estimate} \| f_{k_s} \Phi_{k_s} \|_{L^1} = \|\mathrm{tr} N_{k_s}-2\cos(2\pi k_s\theta)f_{k_s}\|_{L^1} \ge 2-2\cos(2\pi k_s\theta) > c > 0.$$

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: # Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum In this section, we prove Theorem 2. As we mentioned in Section 1.1, the only models known to exhibit critical energies are the critical AMO and the Extended Harper’s operator (for certain parameter values) . Note that zero Lyapunov exponents on the spectrum for the critical AMO was first proved by Bourgain and Jitomirskaya in . Our proof of Theorem 2 follows the outline of the argument in . However, our cocycle map is quite different from the Schrödinger cocycle map as defined in [schrodinger:cocycle]. Moreover, as we have seen in Section 4, our cocycle map is merely meromorphic. These new difficulties again force us to do substantial additional work as in Section 4. We will start by defining the Lyapunov exponents.

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: In this section, we prove Theorem 2. As we mentioned in Section 1.1, the only models known to exhibit critical energies are the critical AMO and the Extended Harper’s operator (for certain parameter values) . Note that zero Lyapunov exponents on the spectrum for the critical AMO was first proved by Bourgain and Jitomirskaya in . Our proof of Theorem 2 follows the outline of the argument in . However, our cocycle map is quite different from the Schrödinger cocycle map as defined in [schrodinger:cocycle]. Moreover, as we have seen in Section 4, our cocycle map is merely meromorphic. These new difficulties again force us to do substantial additional work as in Section 4. We will start by defining the Lyapunov exponents. Let $\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ denote the set of all $2\times 2$ matrices and let $A:{\mathbb T}\rightarrow \mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ be a measurable function satisfying the integrability condition: $$\label{integrability:cocycle} \int_{\mathbb T}\log\|A(\theta)\| \, d\theta < \infty.$$ Then we define a skew product of $T:x \mapsto x + \beta$ and $A$ as follows: $$\label{dynamics:cocycle} (\beta,A):{\mathbb T}\times{\mathbb C}^2\rightarrow {\mathbb T}\times{\mathbb C}^2,\ (\theta,\vec w) \mapsto (\theta+\beta,A(\theta)\vec w).$$ $A$ is the so-called *cocycle map*. The $n$th iteration of dynamics will be denoted by $(\beta, A)^n=(n\beta, A_n)$. Thus, $$\label{iteration:cocycle} A_n(\theta) = \begin{cases} A(\theta+(n-1)\beta) \cdots A(\theta+\beta) A(\theta), &n\ge 1;\\ I_2, &n=0; % \end{cases}$$ Note that $A_n(x)=[A_{-n}(\theta+n\beta)]^{-1}$ for $n\le -1$ if all matrices involved are invertible. One of the most important objects in understanding dynamics of $(\beta, A)$ is the *Lyapunov exponent*, which is denoted by $L(\beta, A)$ and given by $$\label{eq:LE} L(\beta,A) = \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(\theta)\| \, d\theta = \inf_n\frac{1}{n}\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(\theta)\| \, d\theta.$$ The limit exists and is equal to the infimum since $\{\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(x)\| \, dx\}_{n\geq1}$ is a subadditive sequence. If $\beta$ is irrational, then by Kingman’s subadditive ergodic theorem, it also holds that $$L(\beta, A) = \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log\|A_n(\theta)\|,$$ for Lebesgue almost every $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$.

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
Let $\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ denote the set of all $2\times 2$ matrices and let $A:{\mathbb T}\rightarrow \mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ be a measurable function satisfying the integrability condition: $$\label{integrability:cocycle} \int_{\mathbb T}\log\|A(\theta)\| \, d\theta < \infty.$$ Then we define a skew product of $T:x \mapsto x + \beta$ and $A$ as follows: $$\label{dynamics:cocycle} (\beta,A):{\mathbb T}\times{\mathbb C}^2\rightarrow {\mathbb T}\times{\mathbb C}^2,\ (\theta,\vec w) \mapsto (\theta+\beta,A(\theta)\vec w).$$ $A$ is the so-called *cocycle map*. The $n$th iteration of dynamics will be denoted by $(\beta, A)^n=(n\beta, A_n)$. Thus, $$\label{iteration:cocycle} A_n(\theta) = \begin{cases} A(\theta+(n-1)\beta) \cdots A(\theta+\beta) A(\theta), &n\ge 1;\\ I_2, &n=0; % \end{cases}$$ Note that $A_n(x)=[A_{-n}(\theta+n\beta)]^{-1}$ for $n\le -1$ if all matrices involved are invertible. One of the most important objects in understanding dynamics of $(\beta, A)$ is the *Lyapunov exponent*, which is denoted by $L(\beta, A)$ and given by $$\label{eq:LE} L(\beta,A) = \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(\theta)\| \, d\theta = \inf_n\frac{1}{n}\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(\theta)\| \, d\theta.$$ The limit exists and is equal to the infimum since $\{\int_{{\mathbb T}}\log\|A_n(x)\| \, dx\}_{n\geq1}$ is a subadditive sequence. If $\beta$ is irrational, then by Kingman’s subadditive ergodic theorem, it also holds that $$L(\beta, A) = \lim\limits_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac{1}{n}\log\|A_n(\theta)\|,$$ for Lebesgue almost every $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$. Back to our setting, as we have seen from previous sections, we will primarily be interested in the following one parameter family of cocycle maps: $$M^z: {\mathbb T}\rightarrow \mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C}),\ M^z(\theta) = \sec(2\pi \theta) \begin{pmatrix} z^{-1} & -\sin(2\pi \theta) \\ - \sin(2\pi \theta) & z \end{pmatrix},\ z\in\partial{\mathbb D}.$$ The iteration of this cocycle map generates the transfer matrices of our unitary operators $U_{\beta,\theta}$. To avoid poles $M^z(\theta)$, we consider the renormalized cocycle maps: $$N^z(\theta) = -2i \cos(2\pi \theta) M^z(\theta) = \begin{pmatrix} -2iz^{-1} & 2i\sin(2\pi \theta) \\ 2i\sin(2\pi \theta) & - 2i z \end{pmatrix},\ z\in\partial{\mathbb D},$$ which is analytic in $\theta$. Let $L(\beta,z)$ be the Lyapunov exponent of the dynamical system $(\beta, M^z)$. Using the formula [eq:logcosint] for ${\varepsilon}=0$, it is easy to see that $$L(\beta,z) = L(\beta,M^z) = L(\beta,N^z).$$ for all $z$. As an immediate corollary of Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:singspec], we may note that $L(\beta,z)$ is positive for Lebesgue almost-every $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$.
**Corollary 12**. *For irrational $\beta$, the Lyapunov exponent $L(\beta,z)$ corresponding to the family $(U_{\beta,\theta})_{\theta \in {\mathbb T}}$ is positive Lebesgue-almost-everywhere on $\partial {\mathbb D}$.*

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
*Proof.* This is immediate from Theorem [t:uamospec].[t:singspec] and Kotani Theory for CMV matrices . ◻
Next, we define the notion of *acceleration* which was introduced by Avila . Let $A\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C}))$. Then there exists a $\delta>0$ such that we may extend $A$ to an analytic map on the complex domain $\{\theta+i\varepsilon: \theta\in{\mathbb T}, |\varepsilon|<\delta\}$. Let $A_\varepsilon$ denote the complexified cocycle map $A(\cdot+i\varepsilon)$. Then, the acceleration is defined as $$\omega(\beta,A) = \lim_{\varepsilon\rightarrow 0+}\frac{1}{2\pi\varepsilon}\left[L(\beta,A_\varepsilon)-L(\beta,A)\right].$$ The existence of the limit follows from fact that $L(\beta,A_{\varepsilon})$ is convex in ${\varepsilon}$ which follows from the subharmonicity of $L$ in $\theta+i{\varepsilon}$, see e.g. . The following theorem states that acceleration is quantized.
**Theorem 13**. *For any irrational frequency $\beta$ and any $A\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C}))$, $\omega(\beta,A) \in \frac{1}{2} {\mathbb Z}$. If $A\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb C}))$, then $\omega(\beta,A) \in {\mathbb Z}$.*

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
This was first proved in for $\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb C})$-valued cocycles and later extended to $\mathrm{M}_d({\mathbb C})$-valued cocycles in for all $d\ge 2$. As a consequence, $L(\beta,A_\varepsilon)$ is a piecewise affine function in $\varepsilon$. Denote the upper and lower Lyapunov exponents of $(\beta,A)$ by $L_1(\beta,A)\ge L_2(\beta,A)$, where $L_1(\beta,A)=L(\beta,A)$ (see Section 6.1 for a more detailed description). The following theorem is again from .
**Theorem 14**. *$L_1(\beta,A)>L_2(\beta,A)$ and $L(\beta,A_\varepsilon)$ is affine around $\varepsilon=0$ if and only if $(\beta,A)$ admits a dominated splitting.*
See Section 6.1 for the definition of dominated splitting. In light of Theorems 13 and 14, we will consider the complexified Lyapunov exponent $$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon}) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= L(\beta,N_{{\varepsilon}}^z).$$ Notice that by Theorem 13, $\omega(\beta,N_{\varepsilon}^z)\in \frac12{\mathbb Z}$. However, in order to exclude supercritical energies, we will need to avoid the case of fractional acceleration in our setting. Essentially, this follows from the fact that $M$ is meromorphic with all poles on the real axis.

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
**Lemma 15**. *For all $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ and all ${\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$, $$\omega(\beta,N_{\varepsilon}^z) \in {\mathbb Z}.$$*
*Proof.* Using formula [eq:logcosint] and the relation between $N^z$ and $M^z$, we clearly have, $$\label{eq:LE:NtoM} L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon}) = L(\beta,M_{{\varepsilon}}^z) + 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|,\mbox{ for all } {\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}.$$ Notice that for all ${\varepsilon}>0$, $M_{\varepsilon}^z\in C^\omega({\mathbb T},\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb C}))$ which implies $\omega(\beta,M_{\varepsilon}^z)\in{\mathbb Z}$ for all ${\varepsilon}\neq 0$. Hence we obtain $$\label{eq:MN:accelrel} \omega(\beta,N_{\varepsilon}^z) = \begin{cases} \omega(\beta,M_{\varepsilon}^z)+1,\ {\varepsilon}>0,\\ \omega(\beta,M_{\varepsilon}^z)-1,\ {\varepsilon}<0. \end{cases}$$ Consequently, $\omega(\beta,N_{\varepsilon}^z)\in{\mathbb Z}$ for all ${\varepsilon}\neq 0$ by Theorem 13. This in turn implies that $\omega(\beta,N^z)=\omega(\beta,N_0^z)\in {\mathbb Z}$ since $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$ is piecewise linear and continuous in ${\varepsilon}$ for all ${\varepsilon}\in{\mathbb R}$. ◻
By real symmetricity of $\sin(x)$, we have $$N^z(\theta-i{\varepsilon}) = -P\cdot\overline{N^z(\theta+i{\varepsilon})}\cdot P, \text{ for all } z \in \partial {\mathbb D},$$ where $$P= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.$$ Hence, we must have that $L(\beta,z;\varepsilon) = L(\beta,z;-{\varepsilon})$, i.e., the complexified Lyapunov exponent is even in ${\varepsilon}$.

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: **Theorem 16**. *For all ${\varepsilon}$ with $|{\varepsilon}| > 0$ sufficiently large, $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon}) = 2 \pi |{\varepsilon}|$ uniformly for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$.*

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: *Proof.* Let’s first consider the case ${\varepsilon}>0$. Let $G(\theta;z,{\varepsilon}) \overset{\mathrm{def}}=e^{-2\pi{\varepsilon}}N_{{\varepsilon}}^z(\theta)$. Clearly, $$\label{eq:GLE:rel} L(\beta,G(\cdot;z,{\varepsilon})) = L(\beta,N_{\varepsilon}^z) - 2\pi{\varepsilon} = L(\beta,z;\varepsilon) - 2\pi {\varepsilon}.$$ Thus, one has $$G(\theta;z,{\varepsilon}) = \begin{pmatrix} -2iz^{-1} e^{-2\pi {\varepsilon}} & e^{2\pi i \theta - 4\pi {\varepsilon}} - e^{-2\pi i \theta } \\ e^{2\pi i \theta - 4\pi {\varepsilon}} - e^{-2\pi i \theta } & -2iz e^{-2\pi {\varepsilon}} \end{pmatrix},$$ and hence $$\lim_{{\varepsilon}\to \infty} G(\theta;z,{\varepsilon}) = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & -e^{-2\pi i \theta} \\ - e^{-2\pi i \theta} & 0 \end{pmatrix}.$$ Clearly, the convergence above holds uniformly in $\theta \in {\mathbb T}$ and in $z\in\partial {\mathbb D}$. Using this, it is easy to see that, for every $\delta > 0$, there is a constant $M = M(\delta)$ such that $$(1-\delta) \|\vec v\| \leq \| G(\theta;z,{\varepsilon}) \vec v\| \leq (1+\delta) \| \vec v\|$$ for all $\vec v \in {\mathbb C}^2$, all $\theta\in{\mathbb T}$, and all $z\in\partial {\mathbb D}$ whenever ${\varepsilon}\ge M$. Consequently, $L(\beta,G(\cdot;z,{\varepsilon})) = 0$ for all $z\in\partial {\mathbb D}$ for large enough ${\varepsilon}$ by convexity and quantization. The result then follows from [eq:GLE:rel]. Since $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$ is even in ${\varepsilon}$, we thus obtain the result for all ${\varepsilon}$ with $|{\varepsilon}|$ large. ◻

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: **Theorem 17**. *$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})\ge 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|$ for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ and all ${\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$. Moreover, the equality holds if and only if $z\in\Sigma_\beta$. See Figure [f:complexified:LE] for the graph of $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$.*

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text: *Proof.* Since $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$ is both even and convex in ${\varepsilon}$, by quantization of acceleration, Theorem 16 implies that for all ${\varepsilon}\ge0$, the acceleration is either $0$, $1/2$, $1$. By Lemma 15, the acceleration cannot be $1/2$. Thus, by Theorem 16, we have $$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})\ge 2\pi{\varepsilon}$$ for all $z \in \partial {\mathbb D}$ and all ${\varepsilon}\ge 0$. By Theorem 4, $z\notin \Sigma$ if and only if $(\beta,N^z)$ admits a dominated splitting. Since $L(\beta, z;{\varepsilon})$ is even in ${\varepsilon}$, Theorem 14 then implies that $z\notin \Sigma$ if and only if the acceleration is $0$ around ${\varepsilon}=0$. Thus $z\in \Sigma$ if and only the acceleration is $1$ around ${\varepsilon}=0$. By convexity, quantization of acceleration, and Theorem 16, $z\in \Sigma$ if and only if $$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon}) = 2\pi{\varepsilon}, \mbox{ for all } {\varepsilon}\ge0.$$ Since $L$ is an even function of ${\varepsilon}$, the result for all ${\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}$ follows. ◻

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
**Remark 18**. Theorem 16 and the proof of Theorem 17 together give a precise description of the graph of $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$ as a function of ${\varepsilon}$ for all $z\in\partial{\mathbb D}$; in turn, this gives us a precise description of the graph of $L(\beta,M^z_{\varepsilon})$ in ${\varepsilon}$. See Figure [f:complexified:LE] below for the graphs of $L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})$ and $L(\beta,M^z_{\varepsilon})$ both when $z\in\Sigma_\beta$ and when $z\in\partial{\mathbb D}\setminus\Sigma_\beta$. The graphs of $L(\beta,M^z_{\varepsilon})$ also illustrate the following: due to the existence of poles of $M^z(\theta)$ on ${\mathbb T}$, one cannot use $L(\beta,M^z_{\varepsilon})$ to classify energies $z\in\Sigma_\beta$ as supercritical, subcritical, and critical. For instance, $L(\beta,M^z)$ is neither affine nor convex around ${\varepsilon}=0$ for $z\in\partial{\mathbb D}\setminus\Sigma_\beta$.
.5cm

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum
text:
*Proof of Theorem 2.* By Theorem 17, we have $$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon})\ge 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|, \mbox{ for all } {\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R}, \; z \in \partial {\mathbb D},$$ and the equality $$L(\beta,z;{\varepsilon}) = 2\pi|{\varepsilon}|, \mbox{ for all }{\varepsilon}\in {\mathbb R},$$ holds if and only if $z \in \Sigma$. Hence according to the classification in Section 1.1, all $z\in\Sigma$ are critical. In particular, $L(\beta,z)=0$ for all $z\in\Sigma$. ◻
We now have all of the information that we need to prove the remaining part of Theorem [t:uamospec], namely, that $\Sigma$ is a Cantor set of zero Lebesgue measure.
*Proof of Theorem [t:uamospec].1.* Fix $\beta, \theta$ with $\beta$ irrational. By Proposition 12, the Lyapunov exponent $L(\beta,z)$ is positive for Lebesgue almost every spectral parameter $z\in\partial \mathbb D$, and Theorem 2 implies that $L(\beta,z)=0$ on the spectrum. Hence $\sigma(U_{\beta,\theta})$ has Lebesgue measure zero. By ergodicity, $\sigma(U_{\beta,\theta})$ has no isolated points (cf. ), so the theorem is proved. ◻

heading.title: Zero Lyapunov Exponents on and Zero Measure of the Spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices
text: # Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices In this section, we will describe a version of Johnson’s theorem which holds for singular CMV matrices, following the broad outlines of the corresponding result in . We will rely on in this section. In particular, we shall use several theorems in that are asserted in that paper for $z\in \mathbb C\setminus (\partial \mathbb D\cup\{0\})$ and for nonnegative real $\rho$, but are in fact true for $z\in \mathbb C\setminus ( \Sigma\cup\{0\})$ and for complex $\rho$ (see formula [eq:iSU2] for where $\rho$ appears). Here $\Sigma$ is the spectrum of the CMV matrix. It is straightforward to verify that the theorems that we need and quote apply directly to the more general setting.

heading.title: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum
text:
## Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum We first introduce the idea of a dominated splitting, which is a notion from smooth ergodic theory that generalizes uniform hyperbolicity. Let $X$ be a compact metric space, $T:X\rightarrow X$ be a homeomorphism, and $\mu$ be any $T$-ergodic probability measure on $X$. Recall that $\mathrm{M}_2(\mathbb C)$ refers to the set of $2\times 2$ complex matrices. By [dynamics:cocycle], for each measurable $A:X\rightarrow\mathrm{M}_2(\mathbb C)$ there corresponds a dynamical system defined by $$(T,A):(x,v) \mapsto (Tx,A(x)v).$$ We denote the iterates of this cocycle by $(T,A)^n = (T^n, A_n)$. By [iteration:cocycle], $A_n(x)=A(T^{n-1}x)\cdots A(x)$ for integers $n>0$, and $A_0(x)$ is the identity matrix.
**Definition 2**. We further assume $A\in C(X,\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C}))$. Then, we say $(T,A)$ admits a *dominated splitting* (we write $(T,A)\in\mathcal{D}\mathcal{S}$) if there exists a continuous decomposition ${\mathbb C}^2=E^+(x)\oplus E^-(x)$ for all $x\in X$ with $\mathrm{dim}(E^+(x))=\mathrm{dim}(E^-(x))=1$ satisfying the following two properties: 1. For all $x\in X$, $A(x)E^{\pm}(x)\subseteq E^\pm(Tx)$. 2. There exists a $N\in\mathbb Z_+$ such that uniformly for all $x\in X$ and for all unit vectors $v^\pm\in E^\pm(x)$, it holds that $$\lVert A_N(x)v^+\rVert>\lVert A_N(x)v^-\rVert.$$

heading.title: Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum
text: Equivalently, it is not difficult to see that a cocycle $(T,A)$ admits a dominated splitting if and only if there exists $N\in\mathbb Z_+$ and a continuous change of coordinates $Q\in C(X,\mathrm{GL}(2,\mathbb C))$ such that $$\label{eq:diag:DS} Q(Tx)^{-1}A(x)Q(x) = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1(x)&0\\ 0& \lambda_2(x) \end{pmatrix},$$ where $\lambda_1,\lambda_2\in C(X,\mathbb C)$ satisfy $$\label{eq:unif:sep} \prod^{N-1}_{i=0}\lvert\lambda_1(T^ix)\rvert > \prod^{N-1}_{i=0}\lvert\lambda_2(T^ix)\rvert \mbox{ for all } x\in X.$$ Much like uniform hyperbolicity, ${\mathcal{DS}}$ is an open condition in the space $C(X,\mathrm M_2({\mathbb C}))$ which may be detected by an invariant cone criterion.

heading.title: Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum
text: Equivalently, it is not difficult to see that a cocycle $(T,A)$ admits a dominated splitting if and only if there exists $N\in\mathbb Z_+$ and a continuous change of coordinates $Q\in C(X,\mathrm{GL}(2,\mathbb C))$ such that $$\label{eq:diag:DS} Q(Tx)^{-1}A(x)Q(x) = \begin{pmatrix} \lambda_1(x)&0\\ 0& \lambda_2(x) \end{pmatrix},$$ where $\lambda_1,\lambda_2\in C(X,\mathbb C)$ satisfy $$\label{eq:unif:sep} \prod^{N-1}_{i=0}\lvert\lambda_1(T^ix)\rvert > \prod^{N-1}_{i=0}\lvert\lambda_2(T^ix)\rvert \mbox{ for all } x\in X.$$ Much like uniform hyperbolicity, ${\mathcal{DS}}$ is an open condition in the space $C(X,\mathrm M_2({\mathbb C}))$ which may be detected by an invariant cone criterion. For a matrix $A\in\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$, let $\sigma_1(A)\ge \sigma_2(A)$ be the singular values of $A$, i.e., the eigenvalues of $\sqrt{A^*A}$; in particular, $\sigma_1(A) = \|A\|$, the Euclidean operator norm of $A$. Consider a cocycle map $A: X\rightarrow\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ subject to the integrability condition $\int_X\log\|A(x)\| \, d\mu(x) < \infty$ and consider the dynamical system $(T,A)$. Then for $k=1,2$, the *Lyapunov exponents* of $(T,A)$ are defined by $$L_k(T,A) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac1n\int_X\log(\sigma_k(A_n(x))) \, d\mu(x).$$ Moreover, $$L_1(T,A) = L(T,A) := \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac1n\int_X\log\|A_n(x)\| \, d\mu(x),$$ where $L(T,A)$ is the usual (maximal) Lyapunov exponent, as we have already defined in [eq:LE]. Then we say that $(T,A)$ has *nondegenerate Lyapunov spectrum* with respect to the ergodic measure $\mu$ if $$L_1(T,A) > L_2(T,A).$$ Evidently, if $A(x)\in\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb C})$ for $\mu$-a.e. $x\in X$, then $L_1(T,A)+L_2(T,A) = 0$. Hence, in this case, $(T,A)$ has nondegenerate Lyapunov spectrum if and only if it has positive Lyapunov exponent, that is, if and only if $L(T,A)>0$.

heading.title: Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum
text: For a matrix $A\in\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$, let $\sigma_1(A)\ge \sigma_2(A)$ be the singular values of $A$, i.e., the eigenvalues of $\sqrt{A^*A}$; in particular, $\sigma_1(A) = \|A\|$, the Euclidean operator norm of $A$. Consider a cocycle map $A: X\rightarrow\mathrm{M}_2({\mathbb C})$ subject to the integrability condition $\int_X\log\|A(x)\| \, d\mu(x) < \infty$ and consider the dynamical system $(T,A)$. Then for $k=1,2$, the *Lyapunov exponents* of $(T,A)$ are defined by $$L_k(T,A) \overset{\mathrm{def}}= \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac1n\int_X\log(\sigma_k(A_n(x))) \, d\mu(x).$$ Moreover, $$L_1(T,A) = L(T,A) := \lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}\frac1n\int_X\log\|A_n(x)\| \, d\mu(x),$$ where $L(T,A)$ is the usual (maximal) Lyapunov exponent, as we have already defined in [eq:LE]. Then we say that $(T,A)$ has *nondegenerate Lyapunov spectrum* with respect to the ergodic measure $\mu$ if $$L_1(T,A) > L_2(T,A).$$ Evidently, if $A(x)\in\mathrm{SL}(2,{\mathbb C})$ for $\mu$-a.e. $x\in X$, then $L_1(T,A)+L_2(T,A) = 0$. Hence, in this case, $(T,A)$ has nondegenerate Lyapunov spectrum if and only if it has positive Lyapunov exponent, that is, if and only if $L(T,A)>0$. Finally, for any measurable cocycle map $A$ subject to the condition $\int_X\log\|A(x)\|d\mu<\infty$ which admits a bounded measurable conjugacy to the diagonal cocycle as in [eq:diag:DS] (i.e. there exists a bounded measurable map $Q:X\rightarrow\mathrm{GL}(2,{\mathbb C})$ so that [eq:diag:DS] holds for $\mu$-a.e. $x\in X$), it always holds that $$L_k(T,A) = \int_X\log|\lambda_k(x)| \, d\mu(x), \quad k = 1,2,$$ where without loss of generality we assume that $$\int_X \log |\lambda_1(x)|d\mu(x) \ge \int_X \log |\lambda_2(x)|d\mu(x).$$ In particular, if $(T,A)\in \mathcal D \mathcal S$, then it has nondegenerate Lyapunov spectrum with respect to any ergodic measure $\mu$.

heading.title: Dominated splitting and non-degenerate Lyapunov spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Generalized CMV matrices
text:
## Generalized CMV matrices

We will define a class of dynamically defined CMV matrices which are slightly more general than we need. It includes both the standard formalism for CMV matrices and the operators that correspond to the quantum walks considered in the present paper. This class of operators was first introduced in .

Let $f,g$ be continuous functions from $X$ to $i\mathrm{SU}(2)$ (i.e., $\mathrm{U}(2)$ matrices with determinant $-1$). Note that elements of $i\mathrm{SU}(2)$ can be written in the form $$\label{eq:iSU2}
\begin{pmatrix}
\overline \alpha & \rho\\
\overline \rho & -\alpha
\end{pmatrix},$$ where $\alpha\in \overline{{\mathbb D}}$ and $|\rho|^2+|\alpha|^2 = 1$. Notice in particular that $\rho$ may be a complex number.

heading.title: Generalized CMV matrices

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Generalized CMV matrices

heading.title: Generalized CMV matrices

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Generalized CMV matrices
text:
3. $T$ is an isometry, i.e. $d(Tx,Ty)=d(x,y)$ for all $x$, $y\in X$, where $d$ is the metric on $X$. Notice that a minimal translation on a compact metrizable group satisfies all these properties, and thus, the setting at hand applies to all CMV operators with Bohr-almost-periodic coefficients. For instance, the minimal translation on the torus ${\mathbb T}^d$ (corresponding to quasiperiodic potentials) or minimal translations on a compact Cantor group (corresponding to limit-periodic operators) are all of this type. We will need these assumptions for the proof of the following Theorem 19. For instance, as we have used in previous sections, it is easy to see that minimality of $T$ and strong operator convergence imply that the spectrum of $\mathcal E_x$, denoted $\Sigma$, is independent of $x\in X$. Then:
**Theorem 19**. *Let $T$ be a strictly ergodic isometry and suppose that ${\mathrm{supp}}(\mu)=X$. Then we have $$\Sigma = \{z\in\partial{\mathbb D}:(T,A^z_fA^z_g)\notin\mathcal D\mathcal S\}.$$*
Let us consider the set $\mathcal Z = \{x\in X: \rho_f(x)\rho_g(x)=0\}$. This set is of $\mu$-measure zero by [eq:logrhoL1]; in particular, it is a nonwhere dense subset of $X$ since we assumed that $\mu$ is positive on any open subset of $X$. Let us define $$X_0 = X\setminus \left( \bigcup_{n\in\mathbb Z} T^n\mathcal Z \right).$$ In particular $\rho_f(T^kx)\rho_g(T^kx)\neq 0$ for all $k\in\mathbb Z$ when $x\in X_0$.

heading.title: Generalized CMV matrices

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

heading.title: Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum
text:
In this section, we prove the relation $\Sigma \supset\{z\in\partial{\mathbb D}:(T,A^z_fA^z_g)\notin\mathcal D\mathcal S\}$. In fact, we prove a slightly stronger result: $$\label{eq:DSawayspectrum}
{\mathbb C}\setminus (\Sigma\cup\{0\}) \subset \{z\in{\mathbb C}:(T,A^z_fA^z_g) \in \mathcal D\mathcal S\}.$$ In other words, for spectral parameters away from the spectrum of the operators $\mathcal E_x$, the dynamical system $(T,A^z_fA^z_g)$ admits a dominated splitting. We will begin by defining the Carathéodory and Schur functions. It will turn out that the dominating sections will (very nearly) be given by the Schur and anti-Schur functions. The key idea here is to relate Schur functions to Weyl solutions to the difference equation and then use Combes-Thomas type estimates on the solutions to get domination. The details follow.

Notice that ${\mathcal E}_x$ becomes a direct sum of two half line operators if $\alpha_*(T^mx)\in\partial{\mathbb D}$ for $*=f$ or $g$ and for some $m\in{\mathbb Z}$. Then for all $(x,s)\in X\times[0,2\pi)$, we define the half line unitary operators ${\mathcal E}^{(s)}_{x,j,+}$ on $\ell^2[j,+\infty)$ and ${\mathcal E}^{(s)}_{x,j,-}$ on $\ell^2(-\infty,j]$ via the following formula: $$\ \mathcal E_x=
\begin{cases}
\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,2m-2,-}\oplus \mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,2m-1,+}, &\mbox{ if }\alpha_g(T^mx)=-e^{-is}\in\partial {\mathbb D},\\
\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,2m-1,-}\oplus \mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,2m,+}, &\mbox{ if }\alpha_f(T^mx)=-e^{-is}\in\partial {\mathbb D}.
\end{cases}$$ Let $\mu^{(s)}_{g,x,-}$ be the spectral measures corresponding to $\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,-2,-}$, $\mu^{(s)}_{g,x,+}$ to $\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,-1,+}$, $\mu^{(s)}_{f,x,-}$ to $\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,-1,-}$, and $\mu^{(s)}_{f,x,+}$ to $\mathcal E^{(s)}_{x,0,+}$.

heading.title: Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

heading.title: Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum
text:
Then we define functions $\Phi^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z):X\times({\mathbb C}\setminus(\Sigma\cup\{0\})\rightarrow{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}^1$ by $$\label{eq.mtoM}
\Phi^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z)=\frac{1-m^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z)}{1+m^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z)}.$$

The functions $\Phi^{(s)}_{*, -}(x,z)$ (resp. $\Phi^{(s)}_{*, +}(x,z)$) are known as the *anti-Schur* (resp. *Schur*) functions corresponding to $\mathcal E_{x}$, and $m^{(s)}_{*, -}(x,z)$ (resp. $m^{(s)}_{*, +}(x,z)$) are known as the *anti-Carathéodory* (resp. *Carathéodory*) functions corresponding to $\mathcal E_{x}$. Please consult for a thorough exposition of relevant facts on these functions. We will provide a brief summary of Schur and anti-Schur functions here for the reader’s convenience.

An analytic function $\Phi_+$: $\mathbb D \to\mathbb D$ is called a *Schur function*. We may extend such a function so that it takes $\mathbb C\setminus\overline{ \mathbb D}\to\mathbb C\setminus \overline{\mathbb D}$ via $\Phi_+(w)=\overline{\Phi_+(\overline w^{-1})}^{-1}$. In particular, whenever $\Phi_+$ admits a continuous continuation through some $z\in\partial {\mathbb D}$, it must hold that $\Phi_+(z)\in\partial{\mathbb D}$. We call a function $\Phi_-$ an *anti-Schur* function if $1/\Phi_-$ is a Schur function.

The Schur and Caratheodory functions play an important role in the spectral theory of unitary operators, as their limiting behavior on the unit circle gives us information about the spectral measures. For instance, $\Phi^{(s)}_{g,-}(x,z)=-1$ for some $z\in\partial{\mathbb D}$ if and only if $z$ is a pole of $m^{(s)}_{g,-}(x,z)$, which happens if and only if the spectral measure $\mu^{(s)}_{g,x,-}$ has a pure point at $z$, i.e. $z$ is an eigenvalue of ${\mathcal E}^{(s)}_{x,-2,-}$.

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum
text:
This comes from modifying the calculations in . For simplicity, Gesztesy and Zinchenko always assume that the singular Verblunsky coefficients take on the value $\alpha_g(x)=-1$ to get $\mathcal E_x=\mathcal E^{(0)}_{x,-2,-}\oplus \mathcal E^{(0)}_{x,-1,+}$, (and similarly with $\alpha_f(x)=-1$) but if we dispense with that assumption and allow $\alpha_*(x)=-e^{-is}\in\partial{\mathbb D}$ instead, then this results in factors of $e^{is}$ replacing the $1$ in their (2.51) and (2.54), which leads to the $e^{is}$ factors in their (2.57) and (2.58). Notice however that the relation [eq:mfct:solns.alternative] only holds for $x\in X_0$. We may then extend the domain of $\Phi_{*,\pm}(x,z)$ to $X\times({\mathbb C}\setminus (\Sigma\cup \{0\}))$ via $\Phi_{*,\pm}(x,z) = e^{-is}\Phi^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z)$ by arbitrary choice of $s\in [0,2\pi)$. By [eq:mfct:solns.alternative], $e^{-is}\Phi^{(s)}_{*,\pm}(x,z)$ is independent of $s$ for all $(x,z)\in X_0\times({\mathbb C}\setminus (\Sigma\cup \{0\}))$. Notice that $X_0$ is a dense subset of $X$. Hence, $e^{-is}\Phi_{*,\pm}^{(s)}(x,z)$ is independent of $s$ for all $(x,z)\in X\times({\mathbb C}\setminus (\Sigma\cup \{0\}))$ if we can show $\Phi_{*,\pm}^{(s)}(x,z)$ is jointly continuous on $X\times({\mathbb C}\setminus (\Sigma\cup \{0\}))$, which is the consequence of the following lemma.
**Lemma 20**. *The functions $\Phi_{*,\pm}^{(s)}(\cdot,\cdot): X\times (\mathbb C\setminus (\Sigma\cup \{0\}))\rightarrow{\mathbb C}{\mathbb P}^1$, $*=f,g$, are jointly continuous.*
*Proof.* For the sake of simplicity, we will just consider $\Phi^{(0)}_{g,-}$. The proof works the same way for other $\Phi_{*,\pm}^{(s)}$, $*=f,g$. We fix $z_0\in \mathbb C\setminus (\Sigma\cup\{ 0\})$ and $x_0\in X$. To simplify notation, let $\sigma_x=\sigma({\mathcal E}^{(0)}_{x,-2,-})\subset\partial{\mathbb D}$ be the spectrum, and $\mu_x=\mu^{(0)}_{g,x,-}$ be the spectral measure.

heading.title: Dominated splitting away from the spectrum

section_path: Johnson’s Theorem for Singular CMV Matrices / Dominated splitting away from the spectrum
text:
*Proof.* For the sake of simplicity, we will just consider $\Phi^{(0)}_{g,-}$. The proof works the same way for other $\Phi_{*,\pm}^{(s)}$, $*=f,g$. We fix $z_0\in \mathbb C\setminus (\Sigma\cup\{ 0\})$ and $x_0\in X$. To simplify notation, let $\sigma_x=\sigma({\mathcal E}^{(0)}_{x,-2,-})\subset\partial{\mathbb D}$ be the spectrum, and $\mu_x=\mu^{(0)}_{g,x,-}$ be the spectral measure.

Let us endow the space of nonempty compact subsets of ${\mathbb C}$ with the Hausdorff metric and endow the space of normal operators with the metric associated to the operator norm. Then, it is a standard result that the map $N\mapsto \sigma(N)$ (spectrum of $N$) is $1$-Lipschitz continuous with respect to these metrics. Since $T$ is an isometry, ${\mathcal E}^{(0)}_{x,-2,-}$ is a continuous function of $x$, where space of unitary operators is given the operator norm topology as above. Indeed, let us show the continuity for ${\mathcal E}_x$, which is clearly a stronger statement. We have for some constant $C=C(\alpha_f,\alpha_g)>0$, $$\begin{aligned}
 \|{\mathcal E}_x-{\mathcal E}_y\| & \le \|\mathcal L_x\mathcal M_x-\mathcal L_y\mathcal M_x\|+\|\mathcal L_y\mathcal M_x-\mathcal L_y\mathcal M_y\|\\
 & \le \|\mathcal L_x-\mathcal L_y\|+\|\mathcal M_x-\mathcal M_y\|\\
 & \le C\cdot\sup_{n\in{\mathbb Z},*\in\{f,g\}}\{|\alpha_*(T^nx)-\alpha_*(T^ny)|+|\rho_*(T^nx)-\rho_*(T^ny)|\}\\
 & \le C\cdot\sup_{*\in\{f,g\}}\{|\alpha_*(x)-\alpha_*(y)|+|\rho_*(x)-\rho_*(y)|\},

\end{aligned}$$ which clearly implies $\|{\mathcal E}_x-{\mathcal E}_y\|\to 0$ as $d(x,y)\to0$. Notice the last inequality above follows from the facts: $\alpha_*$ and $\rho_*$ are uniformly continuous on $X$ by compactness of $X$; $T$ is an isometry which implies $d(T^nx,T^ny)=d(x,y)$ for all $n\in{\mathbb Z}$. Then we have the following two consequences: $x\mapsto \sigma_x$ is continuous with respect to the Hausdorff metric; and the map $x\mapsto \mu_x$ is continuous with respect to the weak-$*$ topology.
